The Alliance’s work in Korea built on its successful launch at the G20 Young Entrepreneurs Summit in Toronto, Canada in June 2010. Members signed the charter and committed to an ongoing process of engagement with the G20 movement (a copy of the charter follows). November 9, 2010 THE U.S. RUSSIA CENTER FOR ENTREPRENEURSHIP JOINS CANADA IN G20 YOUNG ENTREPRENEUR SUMMIT Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) Next week, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) will join forces with other representatives of the G20 nations at the G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit (G20 YES), hosted by the Canadian Youth Business Foundation (CYBF), to address the role of youth entrepreneurship as the world moves into the post recovery phase. October 28, 2010 Developing into an Entrepreneur Yulia Konstantinova, All About Finance for Small Business magazine by OPORA CREDIT According to a Gallup-Healthways survey, which covered over 100,000 people in the USA in 2009, entrepreneurs and small business owners ranked their level of satisfaction with their work and business environment higher than all other groups of people. Entrepreneurs turned out to be the happiest Americans as perceived by themselves. Victor Sedov , Executive Director of The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, shares his view on the entrepreneurial phenomenon in Russia. December 1, 2009 Entrepreneur: A Very Lonely Occupation Alexander Vasilevsky, Editor-in-Chief, National Business magazine This individual “develops entrepreneurship in Russia the American way, using American methodology.” Continuing with the topic of business education, we talk with Eric Hansen, Vice President of the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE). December 1, 2009 The Price of Human Capital Viktor Nikitin, Professor and Analyst, Azerros Newspaper As a result of special attention to the dynamics of solving problems associated with human capital development in Russia, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of the Russian Federation, with the support and participation of the Russian Ministry of Economic Development, the Federation Council of the Federal Assembly of Russia, and the Government of Moscow, held an international conference on November 9, 2009: “Innovation and Investment: An Effective Basis for the Competitiveness of Russian SMEs in Domestic and International Markets.” December 1, 2009 1 2 © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

Subscribe to receive announcements about upcoming events in your city to receive our e-Bulletin (3 times a year) Last Name First Name Company Title E-mail Telephone City Industry - Agriculture Construction and Real Estate Consulting Food Industry Investor Legal Media NGO Production Other Russian Government Services Technology Transport/Logistics U.S. Government University Education Role Manager Entrepreneur Top Manager Instructor Government Employee Expert Student Other Submit Русский Join us on Facebook Subscribe For announcements of upcoming events and/or our e-Bulletin ﻿ About Programs for Entrepreneurs Youth Entrepreneurship Initiatives Matching Funding Resource Center Entrepreneurship Insights e-Bulletin Videos Press For Donors Partners Contacts ﻿ The Role of Entrepreneurs to be Highlighted at the G20 Summit Press Release Russia forming its Delegation to the G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit (G20 YES) October 31 st – November 2 nd , in Nice, France, in parallel to the G20 summit The third edition of the G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit (G20 YES), the annual international event organized by the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance, that brings together the most emblematic entrepreneurs of the G20 nations, will be held in Nice from October 31 - November 2, 2011. G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance members are currently recruiting young entrepreneurs in their countries to participate in the G20 YES. In Russia, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, which represents Russia in the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance, is finalizing Russia’s delegation of 20 high-potential young entrepreneurs to represent their country at the summit. Russian delegates will be owners of companies in various stages of development and industries. The Russian delegates will be joined at the G20 YES in Nice with over 400 entrepreneurs worldwide, aged between 18 and 45, to discuss how to best harness the potential of young entrepreneurs globally. The resulting recommendations will then be officially handed to the G20 leaders on November 3rd. The measures that summit delegates intend to propose will demonstrate how entrepreneurship can be viewed as the key to overcoming the global recession and a major ally in shaping the economy of an innovative, sustainable and united 21 st century world. This is particularly the case for young people, both in emerging countries and throughout the developed world. These measures are set to respond to the strategic questions pertaining to the mobilization of the resources necessary to strengthen entrepreneurship by underlining to what extent this particular ecosystem defines the growth, the prosperity and the competitiveness of a nation. The proposals will be formally addressed to G20 Heads of state to coincide with their own summit. They are based on two international studies, the first one being undertaken with McKinsey & Company to highlight best practices in favor of enterprise and entrepreneurship. The second one, a barometer of entrepreneurial confidence by Ernst & Young that could serve as a framework for future public evaluation, assesses the means implemented by G20 countries to support entrepreneurs. Previously held in Toronto and Seoul, France is hosting the G20 YES, with the official support of the French President, Nicolas Sarkozy - who will also chair the 2011 G20 Heads of State summit. “Young Russian entrepreneurs are excited to participate in the G20 YES. They are eager to share their experiences in growing businesses in Russia’s emerging economy, to learn from their peers representing other G20 countries, and to contribute to developing recommendations to the G20 leaders that will influence policy initiatives to promote youth entrepreneurship globally.”, states Victor Sedov, President of The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance member that represents Russia. "Thanks to the G20 YES, entrepreneurship has gone from strength to strength on a global scale and this constitutes the beginning of a large-scale movement . The daring innovations of the entrepreneurs, their capacity to create jobs and help small and medium enterprises to develop the flexibility required to face the challenges of today’s globalized world, combined with our capacity to finance and invest in them, represent the key to shaping a desirable 21 st century economy.", says Grégoire Sentilhes, President of the association “Les Journées de l’Entrepreneur” , the French G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance member, which is hosting and organizing this year’s G20 YES. About the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance (G20 YEA): The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance (G20 YEA) is a collective of leading entrepreneurially-minded organizations representing the G20 countries who seek to promote youth entrepreneurship as a powerful driver of economic renewal, job creation, innovation and social change. The Alliance was founded as a movement to engage the G20 leaders in the cause of youth entrepreneurship, share information across borders, affect positive policy change and create a global network of young entrepreneur advocates while building a collaborative entrepreneurial environment worldwide. The G20 YEA provides leadership to G20 political leaders in best practices in promoting youth entrepreneurship through policy recommendations and sharing best practices in the areas of access to funding, coordinating support initiatives, enhancing the entrepreneurship culture, regulation and taxation, and education and training. Annually the G20 YEA organizes the G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit (G20 YES), a 3 day international summit with over 400 entrepreneurs from 18 to 45 years old attending the event from each G20 member country. Delegates work during the summit to finalize recommendations on promoting youth entrepreneurship which are forwarded to the G20 Heads of State during their summit. For more information, please reference the following sites: www.g20yea.com , www.g20yes.com . About The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) has had a significant and measurable impact on advancing the entrepreneurial economy of Russia. Through quality programming, innovative training, and concrete results, CFE has successfully promoted economic development, job creation and increased opportunity for startup and growth entrepreneurs in the country. From its inception in 2002, CFE has identified and developed Russian entrepreneurs; promoted entrepreneurship as a positive force for community well-being; addressed policy issues to enhance a climate for innovation and risk-taking; encouraged others to support entrepreneurship; and advanced entrepreneurship education through programming for youth, the university sector and faculty teaching entrepreneurship. CFE is a founding member and represents Russia on the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance. Please see our website for more information: www.cfe.ru . Morris, Modern Russia There is a global entrepreneurial revolution afoot, and Russia is in its midst.  Free markets represent a highly effective economic structure or system, but they do not work without someone to drive them.  The driver is the entrepreneur.  There is a need for a society filled with individuals with dreams, who will take calculated risks, demonstrate tenacity and perseverance, and creatively overcome the challenges and obstacles that are inherent in creating something new. In Russia, as a generation comes of age born after the fall of communism, we ask, where will the 21st century entrepreneurs come from? As a small part of the answer, Oklahoma State University has partnered with two other universities to take a nationally-recognized entrepreneurship training program to St. Petersburg, Russia.  The Dynamic Entrepreneurship Classroom is an intense, three-day exposure to best practices in entrepreneurship education for university faculty from across the Russian Federation. Importantly, the focus is on more than new venture creation --- it is about the entrepreneurial mindset. Entrepreneurship is about transformation and empowerment. It is concerned with how to recognize opportunity, leverage resources, mitigate risks, and embrace creativity and innovation. Entrepreneurial ventures are responsible for producing more than three-quarters of the new jobs in American society, and they are the dynamic that creates most of the new products, services, processes, markets, technologies and business models. And beyond the start-up venture, the entrepreneurial mindset applies to family firms, non-profit ventures, the public sector, large corporations, and virtually any other organizational context. Entrepreneurship education has no history in Russia. Even in the United States, the emphasis on developing curricula and conducting scholarly research on entrepreneurship has only been prominent for about thirty years.  But the growth has been explosive.  Today, more than 3,000 American colleges, universities and institutes of higher learning offer some sort of entrepreneurship program.  At a number of schools, one can pursue an undergraduate major or minor or a master’s degree in entrepreneurship.  Some universities offer as many as thirty unique courses on different aspects of entrepreneurship.  And the entrepreneurship centers on American campuses are actively involved in economic development activities in their communities. Russia is playing catch up, and is catching up pretty quickly. Business schools are appearing and a number of these are top quality. New entrepreneurship courses are being launched and interesting experiments are underway in terms of creating business start-up incubators, forming networks for entrepreneurs to join, launching business plan competitions, and more. The challenge, however, is that there are very few faculties with any formal training in entrepreneurship education.  Russia currently lacks the infrastructure to support entrepreneurs, and this is where programs like the Dynamic Classroom come into play. For the fifth time over the past few years, Oklahoma State University has joined with Texas Christian University and Syracuse University to share the powerful potential of entrepreneurship with Russian faculty members. The program aims to equip faculty with the tools they need to effectively teach entrepreneurship both within universities and to Russian citizens hoping to start new ventures. These faculty members will reach tens of thousands of students and community residents through their academic programs, incubators, economic development organizations and other entities. Thirty-three Russian faculty members representing institutions throughout the far-reaching Russian Federation were recently exposed to lectures, discussions, experiential exercises and classroom demonstrations. The participants had backgrounds in engineering, economics, accounting, finance and the humanities. They were introduced to leading edge teaching methods, new perspectives on the core content of entrepreneurship, approaches for building a great entrepreneurship program, and novel approaches to experiential teaching and learning. Coordinated on the Russian side by Dr. Galina Shirokova, director of the Center for Entrepreneurship at St. Petersburg University together with the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship , the program brings together top entrepreneurship educators from America to explore how the entrepreneurial spirit can be nurtured in the modern Russian economy . The results have been significant in terms of new courses launched in Russia as well as exciting new approaches to course design and delivery. This includes efforts both within Russian universities as well as programs targeting citizens who want to start businesses. Oklahoma State has also just completed a formal agreement with St. Petersburg University, one of the premier schools in Russia, for ongoing student and faculty exchanges. In spite of the legacy of a planned and controlled economy, it seems that Russians are naturally drawn to entrepreneurship, and opportunities abound.  What stands out from our experiences with the Dynamic Classroom is the hunger among faculty for new techniques and tools for teaching entrepreneurship, and the speed with which they adopt and improve upon these tools in their own classrooms. At Oklahoma State University and our partner colleges, we have embraced entrepreneurship as one of the most powerful tools for change and growth in the world. For us, entrepreneurship is a philosophy, a way of life. It is a means to empower people to build their own futures and the world around them.  It is people creating value, generating jobs, inventing solutions, and producing wealth. Dr. Michael H. Morris is a professor and N. Malone Mitchell Chair head at Oklahoma State University, where he is also the director of the School of Entrepreneurship at the Spears School of Business. IDO – Vi с tor, how do things stand with the culture of technological entrepreneurship and generally the culture of entrepreneurship in Russia today? Compared with the United States, where do we lag behind the most? – To me, it would be better to talk about the culture of entrepreneurship on the whole. Of course Russia does have entrepreneurial culture but compared with many other countries, the USA and euro zone above all, it is still in an embryo stage. This could be best illustrated by figures describing the small and medium business sector contribution to Russian economy. If I am not mistaken, the figure is 21 percent of Russia’s gross national product and the number of SME-employed people is in the area of 20 percent as well of the total able-bodies population. If we are to compare these figures with the USA, France, Germany, even China, we will see that SME is a key sector there, contributing about 60 percent to the overall economy of those countries and employing just as many people, three times more than in Russia. So the Russian figures speak for themselves. We do have a culture of entrepreneurship, and we do have progress in its development, but the development itself is regretfully still very slow. Sure enough, the figures describing SME contribution to the country’s GNP are but some of the parameters of the entrepreneurial culture development level. Other factors to be taken into account include methods of corporate governance and the general level of business transparence, and so on. Hence, if we witness quite a high level of corruption in Russia, this points to the unhappy fact that entrepreneurs often try to get advantages for their businesses not by increasing the transparence of the business or improving the methods of running it but by finding the “right” official who will do something beneficial for the corporation and thus help it “develop” the business. Sadly enough, a lot of Russian entrepreneurs prefer this way of thinking and operating, disregarding other possibilities. – Can this be changed? Can the trend be reversed? And what’s the trick: a certain government policy or the Soviet mentality? – The government policy is officially targeted against corruption. But Russia has such a bureaucratic and multi-level, branched system of government officials, with rather low salaries, too, that this fact is a corruption driver in itself. The psychology of people, no doubt, plays an important role as well. How can this be changed? Strange as it may seem, I don’t think it’s a matter of repression, rather it’s a matter of education, teaching and learning which can give people positive rather than negative examples to follow. This is what can be done and must be done. One of our events was dedicated to business transparence and, more importantly, its cost to the entrepreneur. Some time ago lots of people here would talk about transparence, corporate governance in business, but no one explained how much it cost and what the benefit was. For that event, we used what seemed to us a very good and positive explaining example when we invited a Nizhny Novgorod entrepreneur to Moscow to tell the story of his company. Let me briefly describe it. He had a network of supermarkets and realized the benefit of business transparence. To make everything transparent and clear (accounting, bookkeeping, etc.) he spent around $90,000, quite an amount for a regional entrepreneur. The result was that he approached a U.S. private equity fund, then managed by Delta Capital Management, which, in turn, invested several million dollars in his company to ensure business growth. A few years later, the network and the fund exited the market successfully by selling the supermarket network to Perekrestok, a well-known network retailer. The entrepreneur himself got a profit of several million dollars. So I think this kind of an example, the comparative analysis of business transparence advantages, and the analysis of profitability of investing in transparence made a lot of people think (we arranged the event precisely for Russian entrepreneurs): Is it worth looking for that sought-after official doing “good” for the company at all, and not for free into the bargain? Obviously, the “sought-after official” way may not only lead you to the dock but also is unable as such to let small and medium businesses earn millions. We believe such positive examples, cases as it were, like the one I just described, to be very useful; we believe that printed and electronic media should write and talk about them more than they are doing. If that becomes a fact a lot of people are sure to follow the track. – What are the factors do you think that hamper Russian small and medium businesses’ deeper involvement in innovation activities like the U.S or EU countries? – Some time ago, a lot of attention was paid to this issue by Opora Rossii which made a survey discovering numerous findings. To me, however, one of the biggest problems is rooted in the drawbacks of the Russian system of higher education. For illustration purposes, let me use a U.S. example, namely MIT, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Quite recently, the Kansas City based Kaufman Foundation, a leading institution promoting entrepreneurship globally, published their research findings suggesting that the totality of the companies set up by MIT graduates would be a No. 17 economy in the world (if counted conservatively, under a more liberal counting method they would rank 13th). This is graduates of just one educational institution, I emphasize. The conclusion made by the expert group is evident: the MIT, with the fundamental research school that it has, has built a successfully coexisting unique entrepreneurial ecosystem. They’ve got a Center for Entrepreneurship with proper laboratories. All students get training in entrepreneurship, a separate subject. They have an invention registration division. They have established an excellent relationship with the venture capital community. Here is a real operating model of an innovator or if you wish innovation institution. Now about what they have and we haven’t? Certainly, Russia has lots of excellent institutions of higher learning, some of them with a long research record. The problem is not that we don’t have technical specialists, the problem is that are not taught to know entrepreneurship, a subject that is only beginning to slowly establish in our education. In the U.S., on the contrary, entrepreneurship is taught to students majoring in all subjects, from maths and engineering to history and journalism. They are perfectly well aware that in the future this will help them look for an alternative way of self-employment, self-development, self-realization, not necessarily in a “specific” area but maybe in their own business. And the task of teaching entrepreneurship does not at all boil down to teaching students how to write a business plan. This is just a tool. The task is much more complex, namely teach the student to think “out of the box”, i. e., not in formulaic terms, look for opportunities to implement interesting ideas, take reasonable risks, be responsible, in other words develop qualities that an entrepreneur needs. Therefore, the biggest chair at the Harvard School of Business is the chair of entrepreneurship which practises a case-based method, that is, analyzing success stories of specific companies. This sort of training, using positive examples, is in my opinion very helpful in developing entrepreneurial thinking. What is always very important for the younger generation is success stories, successful people, and talking to them. That is why one obligatory element of such training is inviting successful businessmen as lecturers. We have a long way to go before we get there. In this country there lots of talented researchers and inventors. But nobody teaches them to commercialize ideas, convert them into business projects, get them to the implementation stage and, eventually, to profit. One possible factor which could reverse the situation is a proper infrastructure within educational institutions, such as business incubators and technoparks, but according to numerous independent opinions, most of the existing Russian technoparks is simply business centers letting their spaces, which very often is their only business model. By and large, there is nothing innovative about them. Also, there are apparent imbalances, at least regional: according to media, the Chechen and Karachai-Cherkes Republics have 11 technoparks while the Krasnodar Krai has only one (obviously not enough for Krasnodar). As I mentioned before, even if a region has a technopark its “content” does not always match its “form”. At our end, we are trying to help change the situation; in particular, together with Intel we are developing a training program for technopark and business incubator managers to make sure they work for real innovations, not just profit from letting out their spaces. – But it’s not everywhere like this, is it? – No, it isn’t. Luckily, there are good examples as well. For instance, the Economic Department of Moscow State University has a well-functioning Center for Entrepreneurship, which operates in close cooperation with the Innovation Studio set up with Intel support. They really develop entrepreneurship: we have attended presentations of three companies set up with their assistance and owned by former or current students of the University’s Economic Department. One of them has reached a turnover of $350,000 per month and has created 300 jobs. All the three companies are indeed innovative IT entities. Another company which originated there has now set up a branch in Virginia, and the Americans are happy to see jobs created by Russians. On the whole, I think, the Economic Department of Moscow State University is seeing the birth of the “right” educational-entrepreneurial ecosystem like the one at MIT. – What’s your perception of our technoparks in general, from the western perspective? – By definition, a technopark is a place where innovations are born. They only come to exist where there is an appropriate climate for interchange of ideas, concepts, cultures. Innovations always emerge at a junction of sciences and competencies. Therefore for every technopark, interaction of various experts is vital because an unprejudiced look, say of a biologist and chemist may solve a problem which is unresolvable for a team consisting of say physicists only. This is what innovations are about, an intersection of ideas and knowledge. – What is the role of government support in the field of innovation entrepreneurship development? – In this field, the government plays a very important role. Recently, a lot of important positive steps have been made towards the development of innovative technological entrepreneurship. One of the biggest of those steps is the creation of the Russian Venture Company (RVC). Through RVC and other similar institutions, quite considerable money is invested in the development of small and medium businesses, something that did not exist five years ago. Ironically, we partially owe this to the crisis. It was during the crisis that it became clear that the economy badly needed diversification and could not rely on the mining sector alone. The crisis pushed the government and the economy towards innovative development to resolve the existing problems. It is noteworthy that the Ministry of Economic Development on the whole and its respective department are looking at the western experience, including U.S. experience, and doing quite a good job bearing real fruit. Also the Obama-Medvedev commission is working and its small and medium business subcommission, with useful experience interchange. For example, a delegation of Russian single-industry cities recently visited Pittsburgh, a typical former single-industry place which used to focus on steelmaking only. Owing to economic diversification and SME sector development, the city did not die after the key players of the region’s industry; undoubtedly we can learn from that lesson. Again, the government has made a large number of positive steps in the area of innovation activities development; but more is yet to be done. – What do you think is the first thing to be done? – No doubt, the financial component plays a huge role. I am not talking about direct investments, rather about developing an economic environment where credit resources are available to our innovation entrepreneurs at lower credit rates, for example. But the more important thing to me is support of training. Teach, teach, and teach again. Regretfully, there is often more money (judging by the regional program experience) and affordable credits available for entrepreneurs, more than there are people applying for them. And this fact brings us back to where we started, to the issue of entrepreneurial culture in Russia. At a recent meeting of the U.S. Small Business Administration and Moscow University students, after the audience of 200 people was asked if anybody wanted to become an entrepreneur only one hand went up. In fact, in popularizing entrepreneurship and initiative an important role could be played by media, including government media: society and young people in particular badly need positive examples and success stories. – What is the role of organizations like your Center in shaping entrepreneurial culture in Russia? – Our activities can be divided into three areas. Area one is about entrepreneurship training for college, university and business school professors. For those who can be taught in English, we arrange trainings and trips in the U.S. and Europe; for those who can’t, we arrange foreign trainers’ visits in Russia. By now we have trained about 180 professors in Russia; I must admit, this is not much yet. We have a lot more work to do, but we work hard on this because we view current students as a critical foundation for the perception of ideas of entrepreneurship as such. In what concerns the development of youth entrepreneurship we cooperate with Rosmolodezh among others, offer entrepreneurship lectures at lake Seliger, act as an official organizer of the Global Entrepreneurship Week, represent Russia on the Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance of G20, implement a mentor program together with the International Business Leaders’ Forum, support the Junior Achievement program, and a lot more. Secondly, we have numerous educational programs for entrepreneurs themselves. When a business is developing, the owner needs new knowledge: he needs to know how to work with investors, banks, venture entities, correctly write business plans for a new development stage, and so on. We do not teach this to managers, our educational modules focus particularly on business owners only, i. e., entrepreneurs themselves. After he goes through 9 modules of our Fast Track Planning SM system, an entrepreneur is capable (which is proven by practice) of writing a new business plan for a new stage of his company’s development. I would like to emphasize, these are not programs for startup companies (where in my opinion government support must play a more important role), they are for growing businesses which make the biggest contribution to the gross national product and produce the biggest economic effect. We know from U.S. experience that during the business growth stage it is vitally important for entrepreneurs to communicate with peers, exchange ideas and experience. To this end, we sponsor a large number of business meetings, conferences, round tables, and so on. It is also important to nurture “a culture of success recognition”; in this field, we support numerous entrepreneurship awards and competitions, for instance the Ernst&Young competition of Entrepreneur of the Year. Since this year we’ve had our own award, For Contribution to the Development of the Entrepreneurial Ecosystem. And finally, the third area of our activities – our own analytical and economic research studies which help organizations like Opora Rossii in lobbying changes towards a more favorable entrepreneurial climate in Russia. I want to specifically note that our contribution to the development of entrepreneurship in Russia wouldn’t be so effective without the financial and strategic support of institutions like the U.S.-Russian Foundation for Economic Advancement and the Rule of Law (USRF), Ernst & Young, Intel, and others. – Vi с tor, thank you for a most interesting interview! – Thank you. I would like to wish a merry Christmas and a happy New Year to all your readers. Hopefully, our joint effort will become a weighty, albeit small, contribution to society’s recognition of the importance of developing an entrepreneurial culture in this country. This educational program was developed by the Kauffmann Foundation (USA) and is based on best practices of the U.S school of business. In Russia, it is implemented by the Center for Entrepreneurship in Moscow. The training in Voronezh was unique as it targeted small and socially oriented businesses. Assistance from the Our Future Foundation helped make the seminar attendance free for entrepreneurs and provide accommodation for participants from remote areas of the Voronezh Oblast. Irina Gorelova, coordinator of Youth Business of Russia in the Voronezh Oblast, who also coordinated the implementation of this educational program for the Center, gave a detailed description of the training: “The program consists of 9 modules designed to give basic knowledge in marketing, financial documentation, production, and growth management. For each module, an entrepreneur is invited who uses his business as an example in talking about the subject and shares his experience with the participants. The role of experts at that seminar was played by successful Voronezh entrepreneurs. Vladimir Lisovsky, the General Manager of the Union furniture shop, talked about how to build and motivate a good management team. Grigory Chuiko, the manager of OAO Voronezhselmash, Yuri Segal, the General Manager of OOO Prok, and Gleb Lapenkov, the head of Somovomyasoprodukt, shared their secrets of marketing management in a business. Head of the Sodruzhestvo Association of Auditors, Georgy Popov, the owner of the Lik chain of salons, Lyubov Roshchevkina, and the Executive Director of the Interlingua School of Foreign Languages, Yelena Kuznetsova, shared their experiences in keeping financial documents. Most of the speakers are heavily involved in community work and take part in the Youth Business of Russia program in the Voronezh Oblast as mentors. The facilitator of the program in Voronezh was Maxim Gvozdev, a certified FastTrac® Planning™ trainer, co-owner and General Manager of Lean4systems Group. In 2006, Maxim Gvozdev entered the FastTrac® Planning™ program with the simple purpose of writing a business plan and selling his company. The training dramatically changed his attitude towards his business: Maksim realized that in fact he was running three different businesses, where each requires attention in its own right. He changed his mind and pushed his company to a new level rather than selling it. Lean4systems Group now supports the IT infrastructure of Russian and U.S. companies, develops software, and works in the field of 3D printing. As Maxim put it himself, “Entrepreneurs are the same everywhere; if it’s a living person he will adapt himself to any conditions because he cannot but do business. The audience in Voronezh, by the way, is lively. They are real entrepreneurs and each is a success in his business”. No wonder the facilitator valued his listeners highly: the main criteria of selection for the program was the existence of a running business and its social focus. The result was a group of 23 people from the fields of manufacturing, tourism, education, and services. A majority are individual entrepreneurs, who view their business rather as a hobby or “self-employment”. However, each of them can be with good reason called a socially responsible entrepreneur. For example, some of the program participants give jobs to people released from prison, some train and hire former alcohol and drug addicts. Yevgeny Kuzmin’s company, a small business producing and selling natural lemonades, employs full-time students — a flexible time-table and a good salary help them combine work and education. Vitaly Dedov arranges colored glass master classes for adults and children. During the seminar, students followed the curriculum covering the principal aspects of company operation, for which individual entrepreneurs hardly find time or resources. Their own businesses serve as a permanent aid for student assignments. The results are discussed by groups whose membership is changed by the facilitator all the time, so that everybody can share his experience with people coming from other fields and get to know how they handle similar situations. The training should result in a business plan for company development. According to Vladimir Yatsun, the Doctor-in-Chief of OOO MIP Onkoimmunoprofilaktika, “a socially oriented entrepreneur often thinks that the idea he followed didn’t work. But in actual fact, it may be that it simply was not implemented in full and must be viewed from a different angle. If a business has reached its peak of development one has to look for a new idea and think how to translate it into life. From this perspective, the FastTrac® Planning™ program is unique. One can see that people looked at their businesses, plans and ideas in a different manner and gained knowledge of how to transform it into reality.” Judging by the program participants’ response in Voronezh, they changed their attitudes to business, to say the least. Oksana Fedosova, Organizator Children’s Sport School: “I thought it was my hobby in which I could invest. Here I realized it can be a source of revenue, too, because the idea is welcome in Voronezh.” Vitaly Dedov, Dedov’s Workshop: “I discovered aspects which I am going to use: financial planning, a view of my production facility from the perspective of value gain for the client.” Shifting focus to the client and orientating towards what he gets from dealing with the company is the change in thinking that was noted by a majority of the participants. It is essential to not keep it a theory but strive to translate it into life. My Own Business magazine, November 2012 We are living in the age of information. Having the right knowledge, being in the know, keeping abreast with the times — that’s what makes you strong! The time of new opportunity has come for Russian entrepreneurs. And, their challenge is to rise to that opportunity. You only need to know how. Victor Sedov, President, Center for Entrepreneurship, is confident that it is possible and critical to develop entrepreneurship. What is the mission of the Center for Entrepreneurship? The Center for Entrepreneurship was set up as an initiative of the U.S. Russia Investment Fund. Our goal is to accelerate entrepreneurship in Russia. The Center acts as a catalyst organization expanding the scope of entrepreneurship in this country by combining educational and system-building programs aimed at meeting the interests of growth company leaders. Ten years ago the entrepreneurship situation in Russia was devastating. It still takes a lot of effort to develop it. However, Russia is seeing some positive changes in that arena. By 2020, Russian entrepreneurship is expected to rise to a more acceptable level. The leaders of the country have formulated ambitious tasks, which already is a good thing. The nation realizes that economic diversification is on the agenda. You can’t possibly take care of the raw materials industry. I have spent 20 years in the field of entrepreneurship development. It’s a long way to go yet, but the route is chosen correctly and the necessary steps are being made. How can one help the Russian entrepreneur? By what means? The forms and programs of support are extremely numerous now. Entrepreneurs need specific knowledge. Our Center for Entrepreneurship is different from others inasmuch as it has specially designed educational programs which include individual 4-hour modules dedicated to the most significant problems faced by companies. One program which is very popular in Russia now is the 9-module FastTrac® Planning™. Our trainers are entrepreneurs as well. It doesn’t help much to teach entrepreneurs using professors who have never owned a business or come across typical business problems. Nearly all Russian regional governments have dedicated departments for support of entrepreneurship, various guarantee funds, MSP Bank offering credit resources to commercial banks. At the initial stage of business development, a mentor’s advice is important; this is what Youth Business Russia program, now operating in six Russian regions, is about. The Federal Youth Agency, Rosmolodezh, has developed an important project, You Are an Entrepreneur, designed to increase entrepreneurship awareness among youngsters. What sort of education do entrepreneurs need nowadays? Originally, our target audience was growth entrepreneurs. Developing businesses need contacts, access to capital, equity investment. They are the quickest to introduce new jobs and contribute to the development of the country’s national wealth. Our time and capital costs invested in working with such people pay back the best. FastTrac® Planning™ was designed precisely for such entrepreneurs. It is an art running a company by means of business planning. After reading this course, an entrepreneur can write a new business plan, outline new prospects for himself, and understand how to get there. Our individual modules are useful for both newcomers on the market and for fast growth companies because they provide fundamental knowledge of marketing, strategic planning, personnel planning, and so on. We also make good use of what is called networking, i. e. communication with peers. This form of contact is very useful for a fast growing entrepreneur. Business breakfast meetings help him find the people he needs. For that purpose, we organize entrepreneurial groups in regions where we have a presence. They are locations where entrepreneurs can listen to renowned speakers from Europe and the United States. Is it worth betting on young people today? Young people are exactly what one should bet on. To ensure 50 percent employment in small and medium businesses (the figure now is only 21 percent) we need millions of new entrepreneurs. Our hopes and efforts are meant to ensure that a majority of young people dream of an entrepreneurial career. Students don’t rush to become entrepreneurs today, with only three to four percent prepared to undertake entrepreneurship. To advance entrepreneurship it must be taught at colleges and universities. Look at the Western experience: entrepreneurship is the biggest chair at Harvard today. Entrepreneurship is lectured as a course for students majoring in all subjects. Sooner or later, a student will face a situation where he has to make a decision. It is essential that young people learn to think differently. A business plan alone will not help. A young entrepreneur must be capable of taking the responsibility and reasonable risks. Yet, only some Russian educational institutions work on this. But it is universities who clearly must be abreast with the times. Russia’s future depends on society’s attitude towards the development of entrepreneurship. What was the purpose of setting up the Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development? The goal of the Alliance is to bring the accumulated experience and designed programs to Russian regions. Today, these include Ryazan, Voronezh, Rostov-on-Don, Krasnodar, Kazan, Yekaterinburg, and Chelyabinsk. We’re just at the starting line. Hopefully, all Russia will join us. No country can develop entrepreneurship without a dialog between the government, the educational system, and entrepreneurs. Without joint efforts, we will see no positive results. In a year from now, we shall be summing up the first results. In March, a global entrepreneurial congress will take place in Brazil; in June the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance Summit will be held, with young and successful entrepreneurs from 19 foreign countries and Russia attending. The year 2013 is the year of Russia as a host country. We will suggest that our partners within the Alliance send their entrepreneurs to that summit. The Center for Entrepreneurship hosts the Global Entrepreneurship Week (GEW) in Russia. This ambitious project unites 129 countries and is aimed at developing entrepreneurship globally and entrepreneurial culture, including that in Russia. What prospects of entrepreneurship development do you think await Russia the next ten years? Russia has a huge potential, but compared to the Western world everything is in embryo state here. However, a number of industries show loads of opportunities with room for the development of entrepreneurial initiative. It only takes to pitch in, believing in yourself and without fear. Tens of thousands of people can become entrepreneurs and make weighty contributions to the national economy. What would you wish for the entrepreneurs of the Rostov Oblast? It is very important for them to realize how useful it is to talk to their peers. One shouldn’t try to fight alone. Knowledge is critical. The world is changing so fast that one has to know what’s going on. At the end of the day, this will be your competitive edge. Evgeny Levkin, Head of the new Alliance, in his interview to the Svoe Delo Media magazine: “Our Alliance is another step to improve the entrepreneurial culture in Russia.” Alliance Strategy The Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) came up with an idea of setting up an association of entrepreneurship organizations in early 2012. The reason for that was a constantly increasing number of CFE’s partners in Russian regions wanting access to advanced entrepreneurship development programs in their regions. The strategy of the Alliance is to create a favorable environment - an ecosystem - for developing entrepreneurship in Russian regions. The Alliance’s activities are focused on providing Russian entrepreneurs access to international and national entrepreneurship events, educational programs, and initiatives that promote entrepreneurship as the foundation of economic well-being, and that create a favorable environment for innovation. Join the Alliance The Alliance is open to various kinds of entrepreneurship organizations from any Russian region. The Alliance is neither a lobbyist organization nor an association of entrepreneurs. To qualify as an Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development partner, a legal entity must be an entrepreneurship organization whose main goal is the development of entrepreneurship, and that has the resources and expertise necessary to hold entrepreneurial events and train entrepreneurs and faculty. An organization should sign an agreement with the Center for Entrepreneurship to join the Alliance. New Opportunities After joining the Alliance, a partner may, for example, take part in the 2013 Global Entrepreneurship Congress in Rio de Janeiro on March 18-23, or recruit regional entrepreneur delegates to the 2013 G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance Summit in Moscow on June 15-17, or nominate entrepreneurs in their regions to participate in the Ernst and Young Entrepreneur of the Year Awards. Alliance partners get access to participation in several annual events (conferences, seminars, trainings) of the Center for Entrepreneurship. Alliance partners get assistance in planning and hosting Global Entrepreneurship Week in their region, and have access to sponsorship and co-funding for entrepreneurship development programs in their regions. First Results Since the launch of the Alliance, we observed quite good progress. In October 2012, the Alliance supported the Fashion & Home Startups Forum organized by Startup Women, Alliance partner, and an organization assisting active women entrepreneurs. On November 22, it supported the Svoe Delo (Own Business) 2.0 Russian Forum of Young Entrepreneurship Leaders in Rostov-on-Don. In December 2012, the Alliance in cooperation with its partner in Kazan, Pulsar Venture, held an advanced training course in Technology Commercialization Basics for Innovation Entrepreneurs. Alliance Geography As of the beginning of 2013, Alliance partners activities are pursued in 12 Russian regions: Kaliningrad, Rostov, Ryazan, Chelyabinsk, Sverdlovsk and Voronezh oblasts, Republic of Tatarstan, Stavropol, Krasnodar and Primorsky krays, North Ossetia-Alania and Moscow. In each region, the activities are organized in a different manner, depending on the local opportunities and specifics. Few regions have already conducted joint activities with the Center where as others are still at the planning stage. Alliance expansion The Alliance is following the plan which we jointly designed on the basis of the partners’ wish list and capacity of the Center for Entrepreneurship. We are planning to bring at least 20 active Alliance partner regions on board by the middle of 2014. Education is Important The Center for Entrepreneurship helps entrepreneurs develop practical skills to start and grow their businesses. Russia desperately needs an educational infrastructure capable of offering contemporary entrepreneurship education programs with entrepreneurs training other entrepreneurs and universities developing entrepreneurship education programs to teach the next generation of entrepreneurs. Alliance Bulletin The Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development will be publishing Alliance quarterly newsletter. Below is the first issue covering last quarter of 2012. September 27, 2012 at the Annual Conference “Developing Entrepreneurial Companies” , organized and held as part of the 10th anniversary of the Center for Entrepreneurship, leaders of Russian regional entrepreneurship development organizations signed a Partnership Agreement with the Center for Entrepreneurship to unite efforts in entrepreneurship development by creating the Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development. The Alliance activities focus on providing Russian entrepreneurs access to international and national entrepreneurship events, educational programs, and initiatives that promote entrepreneurship as the foundation of economic well-being, and that create a favorable environment for innovation. The Alliance also promotes entrepreneurship education methodology by promoting entrepreneurship programs in universities and conducting trainings for faculty. To qualify as an Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development partner, an entity must be an entrepreneurship organization whose main goal is the development of entrepreneurship, and which has the resources and expertise necessary to hold entrepreneurial events and train entrepreneurs and faculty. On October 24, the Center for Entrepreneurship supported Fashion & Home Startups Forum organized by Startup Women, a partner of the Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development. The Forum shared trends and prospects of the fashion industry and discussed the importance of start-up developments in fashion. Startup Women is a project for active women entrepreneurs as well as all those who are interested in developing Internet start-ups in the food/fashion/kids/beauty/education area where women are the target audience and the most active customers. The forum became a successful initiative combining projects, home and fashion start-up projects, designers, mentors and investors. The Forum participants included successful entrepreneurs and beginners working on fashion and decoration projects, investors looking at fashion industry projects as good investment opportunities, fashion brand representatives and fashion bloggers, and all those interested in this industry and the ongoing trends. On October 25, Evgeny Levkin attended the 11th Interregional Business Forum in Krasnoyarsk , Entrepreneurship in Siberia , where he made a plenary meeting presentation “Supporting Favorable Ecosystem of Entrepreneurship in Russian Regions” and met with potential partners of selected regions. On October 26, Evgeny Levkin attended the 7th Interregional Conference “Small Business Development: Instructions and Practices” , held by the Expert-Ural magazine in Yekaterinburg, and made a presentation “Supporting Favorable Ecosystem of Entrepreneurship in Russian Regions”. On November 30, Evgeny Levkin spoke at a round table “Prosperity of SMEs - Core Element of Competitiveness in Russia and CIS” at the International Conference, “Competitiveness of Russian Regions: innovations, investments, partnerships” . In Moscow on November 9, CFE’s leadership exposed Alliance partners to opportunities provided by the Center in the Global Entrepreneurship Week, the Global Entrepreneurship Congress, Entrepreneur of the Year Award, G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance Summit and the Annual conference on entrepreneurship education. The CFE’s staff and Alliance partners shared their experience in organizing and delivering four-hour training modules, FastTrac ® Planning TM , Dynamic Entrepreneurship Classroom and Managing an Efficient Business Incubator and Techno-park workshops, designed for entrepreneurs, entrepreneurship trainers, and leaders of entrepreneurship organizations from Russian regions. On November 22, Rostov-on-Don saw the Russian Forum of Young Entrepreneurship Leaders held to draw the public’s attention to youth entrepreneurship problems and involve young people in business activities. The Russian Forum of Young Entrepreneurship Leaders was organized in partnership with the Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development and financially supported by the Center for Entrepreneurship. During the Svoe Delo 2.0 Russian Forum of Young Entrepreneurship Leaders there was an open exchange of opinions between members of various support programs in that area, discussions with government authorities and young entrepreneurs, and presentations of Russian and foreign business development practices and business projects. The event participants discussed issues related to funding of a start-up company, innovation implementation, and generation of entrepreneurial knowledge among youngsters. Eric Hansen, Vice-President of the Center for Entrepreneurship, made a presentation at the Forum “Teaching entrepreneurship at a higher school: initiatives to support teaching the basics of entrepreneurship in Russian universities”. On December 1-23, 2012, the Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development and Pulsar Venture, with the financial support of the Center for Entrepreneurship arranged an advanced training course in Technology Commercialization Basics for Innovation Entrepreneurs. During three weeks, over 50 leaders of Tatarstan innovation companies had a chance to master modern business management skills so that later they could develop their projects and commercialize their research findings. The advanced training course included five 4-hour trainings of the Center for Entrepreneurship and a 32-hour-long FastTrac ® Planning TM , the program to improve strategic business planning skills to uncover the potential of your businesses. From June 20-22, 2010, CFE will join the international delegations in Toronto, Canada, to identify and examine the issues challenging young entrepreneurs and entrepreneurial organizations around the world. The discussion points from the G20 YES will be drafted into a communiqué that will be officially handed over to the G20 Business Summit (B20) for deliberation. The G20 YES has been recognized by the Canadian federal government as part of the G20 consultative process and its recommendations are planned to be the focus for a discussion of entrepreneurship at the B20 Summit on June 25 and 26, 2010. "Young entrepreneurs are vital contributors to global economic development. Only through open discussion can we address the needs and recognize the challenges facing these innovative young people on an international scale," says Vivian Prokop, chief executive officer of CYBF and chair of the G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit. "We are honored that The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship has joined CYBF for the G20 YES. By working towards a common goal, this global alliance of entrepreneurship organizations will identify the necessary action to help promote and encourage youth entrepreneurship around the world." Victor Sedov, CFE President adds, "By bringing the issues surrounding youth entrepreneurship to an international stage, the G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit can be an important catalyst for promoting entrepreneurship among future generations, and to promote innovation, job creation and opportunities for self fulfillment." The G20 YES is funded in part by the generous support of the Government of Ontario, National Post, Clear Channel Outdoor Canada, Hill&Knowlton, The Keg Steakhouse&Bar, MaRS Discovery District, Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC), Scotiabank Small Business, Elastic Path Software, Invest Toronto, KPMG Enterprise, Outdoor Broadcast Network and RBC Royal Bank. About The Canadian Youth Business Foundation (CYBF) Canada’s Entrepreneur Gateway The Canadian Youth Business Foundation (CYBF) is the "go to" place for youth entrepreneurship. As a national charity, we are dedicated to growing our nation’s economy one young entrepreneur at a time. We look at character not collateral, when providing youth, age 18–34, with pre-launch coaching, business resources, start-up financing and mentoring, to help them launch and sustain a successful entrepreneurial business ( www.cybf.ca ). About the CYBF G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit The Canadian Youth Business Foundation (CYBF) will host the G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit (G20 YES) in Toronto, Canada, from June 20 to 22. The G20 YES will bring together more than 200 young entrepreneurs (aged 18 to 40) and leaders of entrepreneurial organizations from G20 countries to exchange ideas and establish international networks and partnerships that will help drive sustainable global economic growth. The G20 YES has been recognized by the Canadian federal government as part of the G20 consultative process and its recommendations are planned to be the focus for a discussion of entrepreneurship at the G20 Business Summit (B20) on June 25 and 26, 2010  ( www.cybf-g20.com ). About The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) has had a significant and measurable impact on advancing the entrepreneurial economy of Russia. Through quality programming, innovative training, and concrete results, CFE has successfully promoted economic development, job creation and increased opportunity for startup and growth entrepreneurs in the country. From its inception in 2002, CFE has identified and developed Russian entrepreneurs; promoted entrepreneurship as a positive force for community well-being ; addressed policy issues to enhance a climate for innovation and risk-taking ; encouraged others to support entrepreneurship; and advanced entrepreneurship education through programming for youth, the university sector and faculty teaching entrepreneurship. Subscribe to receive announcements about upcoming events in your city to receive our e-Bulletin (3 times a year) Last Name First Name Company Title E-mail Telephone City Industry - Agriculture Construction and Real Estate Consulting Food Industry Investor Legal Media NGO Production Other Russian Government Services Technology Transport/Logistics U.S. Government University Education Role Manager Entrepreneur Top Manager Instructor Government Employee Expert Student Other Submit Русский Subscribe For announcements of upcoming events and/or our e-Bulletin ﻿ About Programs for Entrepreneurs Youth Entrepreneurship Initiatives Matching Funding Resource Center Entrepreneurship Insights e-Bulletin Videos Press For Donors Partners Contacts ﻿ G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance Meets in Seoul Prior to the G20 Summit November 9, 2010: Seoul, South Korea. Leading organizations representing millions of young entrepreneurs in countries across the G20 signed a charter outlining a framework of how it will engage the G20 process to include entrepreneurship in its ongoing agenda. The G20 Young Entrepreneurs Alliance (YEA) is made up of the leading organizations that support young entrepreneurs around the world. In recognition that entrepreneurship is now, more than ever, at the heart of the new 21st century economy, it has committed to sharing best practice on the entrepreneurial ecosystem within each of its member nations to further enhance competitiveness, growth, job and wealth creation. The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship represents Russia on the G20 YEA. The Alliance’s work in Korea built on its successful launch at the G20 Young Entrepreneurs Summit in Toronto, Canada in June 2010. Members signed the charter and committed to an ongoing process of engagement with the G20 movement (a copy of the charter follows). Through its role as the forum for championing the cause of G20 emerging entrepreneurs, Alliance members will also share experiences, initiatives and policies going forward in building entrepreneurial economies and fostering entrepreneurship in G20 nations and worldwide. "We, Young Entrepreneurs' Society of Korea (YES Korea), are so pleased to be the host of G20 Young Entrepreneurs Summit, Seoul, Korea.” said Michael Lee, CEO of the organization. “All representatives discussed strategies for making the G20 YEA an even more impactful and sustainable global movement." The Alliance will meet prior to each G20 leaders’ summit. The next meeting will be taking place in France in November 2011 and will be hosted by Les Journees de l'Entrepreneur. "We are proud to organize the next G20 Young Entrepreneurs Summit in France,” said Gregoire Sentilhes, Chairman of the organization. “Our ambition is to inspire the future generation of entrepreneurs and foster the hope attached to entrepreneurship as the social and economic link between government and citizens". The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance (YEA) is a global network of young entrepreneurs and the organizations that support them. YEA was established to convene each year in advance of the G20 Summit to champion the importance of young entrepreneurs to the G20 member nations and to share our own examples and practices. The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) is a development organization that promotes economic opportunity, helps build a strong middle class that strengthens civil society and democracy, and enhances the relationship between Russia and the US. CFE identifies and develops entrepreneurs throughout Russia and provides them with the knowledge, skills and personal abilities to start and build growth companies. It enhances a culture of entrepreneurship by raising awareness of entrepreneurship as an engine for economic development and job creation, and expanding the capacity of entrepreneurship support organizations. And, CFE advances entrepreneurship education at the university level to inspire future generations of entrepreneurs. For more information, please contact: Eric Hansen Vice President The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship +7-499-929-7927 www.cfe.ru Incheon Charter of the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance November 7 – 9 2010, Incheon, South Korea The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance Meeting, in Incheon, this 9 th day of November 2010, recognizes that young entrepreneurs are powerful drivers of economic renewal, job creation, innovation and social change. We, the Members of the Alliance, recognize the need to bring together organizations from industrialized and developing economies to champion the cause of young entrepreneurs. Building on our engagement at the June 2010 Toronto G20 Summit, we, the Members of the Alliance, commit to a long term engagement of the G20 as an extension of our missions to champion the cause of young entrepreneurs in our respective countries and across the globe. Through our global movement, we believe we can make the 21 st century the Century of the Entrepreneur. We, the Members of the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance, have set forth the following Charter: WHO WE ARE The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance (YEA) is a global network of young entrepreneurs and the organizations that support them. We have been established to convene each year in advance of the G20 Summit to champion the importance of young entrepreneurs to the G20 member nations and to share our own examples and practices. OUR VISION We, the signatories of this Charter, envision: (1) a network that, through its discussions with governments, the media, the public and each other, champions the cause of young entrepreneurs at the local, national and international level. (2) an alliance of organizations from industrialized and developing economies that makes measurable progress towards its goal of a world where an increasing number of entrepreneurs grow businesses, create jobs, change lives and ensure future economic prosperity. (3) a recognized body that exists as part of the official G20 process and is able to engage, contribute to and impact the findings of the G20 to raise awareness and address the issues of emerging entrepreneurs across the globe. OUR BELIEFS We, the signatories of this Charter, believe that: (1) as entrepreneurs found their businesses and change their own lives, they are important contributors to social change, job creation and economic renewal. (2) strengthening the support of entrepreneurs and providing opportunities for international cooperation will help foster economic growth and development across the globe. (3) advocating the cause of emerging entrepreneurs and promoting their importance will prepare the next generation for the renewal and growth of our economies and societies. (4) a recognized alliance of diverse organizations will empower our influence and legitimacy. (5) supporting the dreams of these entrepreneurs is a top priority and should be an increasing priority for the governments of the G20. OUR COMMITMENT TO YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS The signatories of this Charter commit to: (1) supportand encourage young entrepreneurs across the globe. (2) strengthen international cooperation and promote open and constructive discussion on key issues relating to the support and growth of young entrepreneurs. (3) share information and resources among Members for the benefit of young entrepreneurs. (4) engagethe G20 and provide a forum for the discussion of issues found by young entrepreneurs. Entrepreneurs turned out to be the happiest Americans as perceived by themselves. Victor Sedov , Executive Director of The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, shares his view on the entrepreneurial phenomenon in Russia. Mr. Sedov, does it take to be born an entrepreneur or is it a matter of development? Difficult to say. Some studies result in quite specific findings suggesting that students who read entrepreneurship, among other things, start up a business of their own much more frequently than those without entrepreneurship training. This is an expected result, suggesting that entrepreneurship can and must be taught, the sooner the better, exactly like in any other field. Learning foreign languages, for example, is much easier in childhood. The same is true of mastering skills. Of course, one can be naturally predisposed to entrepreneurship in the same way as to any other activity. The younger generation now has a very good entrepreneurial potential. They don’t have the legacy of the Soviet past which threatened entrepreneurs with criminal prosecution. They are strong, enthusiastic and confident of success. Studies indicate that the desire to start up a business declines dramatically among people older than 25 years of age because they are much more prudent in weighing all the risks of enterprise, they are more skeptical as they realize the complexity of running a business of their own. President Medvedev recently announced that the number of those employed in Russian small businesses should be raised to 70 percent by 2020, whereas it is 10 percent now. In my view, we shall be able to arrive at that figure only if we take the issue of entrepreneurship education seriously and show the younger generation instruments to help them meet their entrepreneurial ambitions. But what do you think is Russia’s main obstacle to starting a business of one’s own: lack of startup capital, administrative barriers, or insufficient information? Serious administrative barriers do exist despite certain measures to reduce them that the government has been undertaking recently. However, the information field is quite broad in these issues. Also, there are opportunities to raise financial resources. So, I would say that it’s a matter of psychology. Is it true that a lot of beginning entrepreneurs avoid credits and prefer borrowing from family members or friends because the Russian mentality prevents them from living on borrowings? Business development using borrowings is a typical and quite usual thing, both in Western countries and in Russia. “Family” money is absolutely sufficient to successfully run a small family business, like a small shop. But when it comes down to business development one has to raise a different scale of funding. The difference is that borrowings are cheap in the West while the credit rates in Russia are very high. Moscow offers beginning entrepreneurs up to 350,000 rubles support grants, on a competition basis subject to certain conditions. Do you think it is much or little? It depends on what and where your business is. For Moscow it may be little, but somewhere in the province it may be enough. It’s not so much a matter of lack of funding, but rather lack of quality projects and original ideas. Last August, A. Sharov (head of Small and Medium Business Support Department, Ministry of Economic Development - editor’s comment ) said that funds for small business support have been allocated, they are available but there are very few people who are eligible for those funds. There are no interesting business ides, so the funds are very likely to stay unexpended. I’m afraid I can’t agree with you. The Internet is full of stories by people who failed to get through the administrative procedures and get grants. I am not saying getting these funds is as easy as it may seem to someone. I also admit that occasionally some things are simply not properly designed administratively. Just one example that everyone is talking about and I have personally faced: re-registration of limited liability companies. The re-registration mess, which arose for lack of distinct explanations from the Federal Tax Authority and poorly engineered procedure, was quite broadly covered in the press. Mr. Sedov, for several years you have been on the jury panel of the Entrepreneur of the Year international competition. This year you chaired the panel, so you are in a position to judge how much Russian entrepreneurs are competitive on the global market? Over the years of the competition, we have seen a rising number of Russian participants and a rising share of small business participants. Last year, for example, there was a separate nomination established for family business. As regards international competitiveness, I must say that the finalists of the national stage include very impressive nominees; suffice it to mention the winners of previous years, like Ruben Vardanyan, President of the Troika Dialog Group, Sergei Vykhodtsev, President of VELLE, and others to realize that people like them are competitive at any level. How important is the “human factor” in determining the winner? Entrepreneur of the Year winners are determined by a national jury composed of previous years’ finalists of the competition, independent experts, prominent businesspeople. I must emphasize, Ernst & Young themselves do not sit on the panel. The criteria of winner selection include both quantitative factors like the growth rate of the company’s turnover, profit and number of jobs, and qualitative aspects like the degree of innovation in the business practices, the development of original products, creative marketing and sale solutions, the scale of national and international presence, implementation of personnel development programs. The winner is selected against a combination of all these factors. The US-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship initiated the setup of the Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education. What is the purpose of the Association? The Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education was established in 2008. It is expected to make the best western and Russian experience available to all those who want it. The United States Association for Small Business and Entrepreneurship (USASBE), which has been successful in the USA for 52 now, was taken as an example to follow. Geraldine Franklin, President of USASBE and Dean of the Business College at South Florida University, made a special trip to Moscow to tell her counterparts about the USASBE setup. Under the operation model of the Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education, leading university professors from Moscow, St. Petersburg and other Russian regions take a course of training abroad to be able to teach entrepreneurship in Russia later. This creates a strong chain: professor training - student training - setup of small businesses by former students. We have seen the first results. For instance, the Economic Department of Moscow State University has set up a Center of Entrepreneurship, and an entrepreneurship training course has been designed in St. Petersburg on the basis of Russian business cases. It is a very important step because a review of US business cases in the Russian environment is not always possible or reasonable, while the above course analyses, among other things, the experience of “the Russian McDonald's”, the ChainayaLozhka chain in St. Petersburg, a leader on the local restaurant and fast food market. Following this model, the Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education will be able to identify the best Russian curricula and set up higher-level entrepreneurship education standards on that basis. The Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education includes about 70 members now. And yet, what is it that determines a successful business? Professional qualities alone or luck, a happy chance? To be able to use a chance one has to be prepared for it. Take Oleg Tinkov for example. He launched his credit card project much later than others and seemed hopelessly behind everybody else. But this is precisely what helped him and his project a success. It is a combination of business intuition and an understanding of what the market needs at this specific moment in time. Entrepreneurial skills are like a sail that must be driven by wind - circumstances, chance, luck. But the boat is not going anywhere without the sail. What would you wish for the readers of OporaKredit ? My impression is that in covering entrepreneurship the media tend to focus on negative facts associated with small businesses, like tax dodging for example, rather than quote success stories. From that perspective, I like the Entrepreneur of the Year awards because it inspires and sets a positive example to everyone. This is why I see the OporaKredit project as very useful: it provides important practical information for those involved in small business activities or planning to do so. I wish for OporaKredit readers to be persistent in striving towards their goals and being successful! The international competition, Entrepreneur of the Year, supported by Ernst & Young, has been held in 50 countries of the world for over 20 years . Russia has held the national stage of the competition since 2003 . On November 26, 2009, the Entrepreneur of 2009 award ceremony took place in Moscow ; the winner was Oleg Khusaenov, General Manager of Atlant-M, a holding company .
