- News russian version News Russian Association for Entrepreneurship Education is Launched For The Russian Association for Entrepreneurship Education is designed to make the best western and Russian practices available to all who are eager to absorb it.  It was initiated by The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship which organized a working group meeting attended by about 20 leading Russian universities, business schools and entrepreneurs involved in training. The template for the Association was the United States Association for Small Business and Entrepreneurship (USASBE), which has been successfully operating in the USA for 52 years. Geralyn Franklin, President of USASBE, and Dean of the College of Business at the University of South Florida, came to Moscow specifically to tell her colleagues about the structure of USASBE, an organization that unites about 800 people disseminating knowledge about SMEs and entrepreneurship.  They include scholars, authors of training courses in psychology and dramatic art, as well as professors of classical business subjects.  USASBE members are entitled to free journals and information bulletins in the field of entrepreneurship; they improve their skills at seminars and workshops; and they meet annually for a major conference in various cities of the US.  USASBE is not confined to US practices, and is part of the International Council for Small Business. Following the above model, the Russian Association for Entrepreneurship Education will be able to identify the best Russian programs and use them as a basis on which to establish higher levels of training.  Association members will regularly take part in workshops and conferences abroad thus creating a bridge via which the most up-to-date entrepreneurial knowledge will enter this country. Ludmila Murgulets, Vice President of the Stockholm School of Economics in St. Petersburg, has been elected President of the Russian Association for Entrepreneurship Education. For details about the new business association, call the U.S.-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship at (495) 252-7927 or write to Ms. Alla Danilova of the center at: adanilova@cfe.ru . - News russian version News 29 Febriary Moscow Entrepreneurship Group:Outsourcing for Growth:Minimizing Risks and Increasing Efficiency Entrepreneur  Irina Nikiforova, President , Zimaletto , will focus on why his company decided to use outsourcing, the criteria used in choosing partners, steps in outsourcing, controlling quality when outsourcing, and efficiencies gained when using outsourcing. Entrepreneur  Mikhail Khazov, President, Kosmoteros, will present a case study on an unsuccessful outsourcing experience and lessons learned and advice on how to choose an outsourcing partner. Service Provider  Inna Kachalova, Lawyer , Pepeliaev, Goltsblat & Partners will discuss the legal aspects of outsourcing; contracts; outsourcing activities subject to licensing; and responsibility of an outsourcing company, and methods to ensure they deliver. Consultant  Vyacheslav Lev, Associate Partner, and Natalia Oparina, Partner, Top-Management Consult , will discuss outsourcing myths; pluses and minuses of outsourcing; how to estimate if outsourcing is economically justified; how to minimize outsourcing risks; and will give advice on personnel outsourcing. In addition, our programs help entrepreneurs overcome environmental challenges that hinder company growth, such as protecting intellectual property, utilizing the legal system, and approaching capital providers. CFE utilizes a robust delivery methodology, including: focused courses; workshops; peer learning events; and networking opportunities. These programs foster not only entrepreneur-to-entrepreneur , but also mentor-to-entrepreneur , entrepreneur-to-investor , and entrepreneur-to-policymaker learning. By bringing together all of the players that influence entrepreneurial success, CFE offers unique, integrated and experiential learning programs. "I am a co-founder of numerous companies. The event  provided entrepreneurs with a platform to discuss best practices in leading their company’s growth, including how to use information technology, personnel management, raising capital, and the role entrepreneurs play in creating jobs, national wealth and developing society. Event Agenda: 9:30 – 9:45 - Welcome address to participants and overview of the conference agenda Victor Sedov , President, Center for Entrepreneurship 9:45 – 10:45 – "The Entrepreneurial Ecosystem" Jonathan Ortmans, President, Global Entrepreneurship Week; Senior Fellow, Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation; Chairman, Global Entrepreneurship Congress I nternationally renown expert in building effective entrepreneurship ecosystems, Mr. Ortmans  discussed global best practices in creating conditions for fostering small and medium businesses, how to develop a culture that embraces entrepreneurship, and compared the experiences in developing and developed countries in advancing entrepreneurship. 10:45 – 12:00– Moderated Discussion “Russia’s Entrepreneurial Ecosystem: Today and Tomorrow” In this discussion, experts discussed the process of creating an healthy entrepreneurship eco-system in Russia. Moderator - Sergey Borisov, President, "OPORA RUSSIA" Panel Members: Natalia Larionova, Director, Department of Small and Medium Business and Competition, Ministry of Economic Development of the Russian Federation Elena Bocherova , Deputy Director, Federal Agency for Youth Yury Rubin , President of Russian Association for Entrepreneurship Education (RAEE),Rector of Moscow University for Industry and Finance "Synergy" Olesya Teploukhova, Deputy Chairman of the Board, member of the board Oscar Hartmann , General Director, KupiVIP; President, Foundation of Russian Economy 12:00 – 12:20 – Coffee Break 12:20 -13:30 – Sales: International vs. Regional Expansion Case Studies Presenters: Entering the U.S. and European Markets Andrey Korneev , Chief Executive Officer, Research Center Bioform Alex Kosik, СEO, Gravitonus Inc. Developing Regional Businesses Oleg Husaenov, Chairman of the Board, International Automobile Holding, Atlant-M 13:30 – 14:30 – Lunch 14:30 – 17:00 – Creating Effective Business Models Master Class by Patrick van der Pijl, СEO, Business Models Inc. Expert and producer of the global bestseller, “Business Model Generation: A Handbook for Visionaries, Game Changers, and Challengers”. Mr. van der Pijl gave a practical master class on the most effective ways to optimize your organization’s business model to grow your business and increase sales. The world is changing at a high speed. The shelf life of business models becomes shorter and shorter. We need new tools and skills to understand, design and innovate business models. Patrick provided an introduction to why business modelling is so popular, explaining the business model canvas and providing practical examples of how you can innovate and test your own business model. 17:00 – 17:20 – Coffee Break 17:20 – 17:40 - Open Innovation as an Instrument to Grow Entrepreneurial Companies Ekaterina Inozemtseva , Strategy Director, Skolkovo Foundation 17:40 – 18:00 – Creating an Innovation Lab and Managing Innovation in your Business (Case Study) Yan Abubakirov , General manager, a group of companies "TETRA Electric" 18:00 – 18:20 – Signing Ceremony for First Members of the Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development 18:20 – 18:30 – Conference Closing 18:30 – 21:00 – Gala celebration honoring the 10th anniversary of the Center for Entrepreneurship and the Entrepreneurship Ecosystem Awards ceremony Participation fee: The fixed price for all entrepreneurs: 9000 rubles (including VAT); Sponsors: Strategic Partner: Sponsors: Supported by the entrepreneurial companies: Information Partners: Exclusive Sponsor of the reception: Download Material 's presentation (pptx, 1.07 MB) 's presentation (pptx, 1.58 MB) 's presentation (pptx, 1.71 MB) 's speech (ppt, 5.25 MB) Photos 1 of 6 Videos В вашем браузере отключен JavaScript ← Return to Events List © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

At the meeting the members of Entrepreneurship Group had an opportunity not only to communicate in a comfortable atmosphere but to meet new, interesting people, and get useful information. We had invited speakers, successful representatives of the Nizhny Novgorod and St. Petersburg business, who spoke about practice of their companies in the context of the unit. Guest-cpeakers: Andrey Popov (business development consultant "Subway Rush Service Company, St. Petersburg) spoke about creating a successful franchise network as an example of fast food chain SUBWAY; gave valuable advice to entrepreneurs who were interested in buying a franchise. Marya Iljina (Director of franchising project Spar Middle Volga, Nizhny Novgorod, Russia) talked about how to build relationships between the franchisor and the franchisee, the typical mistakes that both parties commit and how to avoid them. Michael Trishin (Director General of OOO "Consult Studio", the author of Russia's first tutorial on the development of the franchise package: http://infopraktik.ru/product/ # 1) talked about the development of a franchise package and building franchise network, as well as the difference between foreign and "our" franchise. Alexander Skornyakov (Director of Franchise Network of cafeterias "Tea Spoon", St. Petersburg) shared his experience of working at a franchising company "Tea Spoon." The event  provided entrepreneurs with a platform to discuss best practices in leading their company’s growth, including how to use information technology, personnel management, raising capital, and the role entrepreneurs play in creating jobs, national wealth and developing society. Event Agenda: 9:30 – 9:45 - Welcome address to participants and overview of the conference agenda Victor Sedov , President, Center for Entrepreneurship 9:45 – 10:45 – "The Entrepreneurial Ecosystem" Jonathan Ortmans, President, Global Entrepreneurship Week; Senior Fellow, Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation; Chairman, Global Entrepreneurship Congress I nternationally renown expert in building effective entrepreneurship ecosystems, Mr. Ortmans  discussed global best practices in creating conditions for fostering small and medium businesses, how to develop a culture that embraces entrepreneurship, and compared the experiences in developing and developed countries in advancing entrepreneurship. 10:45 – 12:00– Moderated Discussion “Russia’s Entrepreneurial Ecosystem: Today and Tomorrow” In this discussion, experts discussed the process of creating an healthy entrepreneurship eco-system in Russia. Moderator - Sergey Borisov, President, "OPORA RUSSIA" Panel Members: Natalia Larionova, Director, Department of Small and Medium Business and Competition, Ministry of Economic Development of the Russian Federation Elena Bocherova , Deputy Director, Federal Agency for Youth Yury Rubin , President of Russian Association for Entrepreneurship Education (RAEE),Rector of Moscow University for Industry and Finance "Synergy" Olesya Teploukhova, Deputy Chairman of the Board, member of the board Oscar Hartmann , General Director, KupiVIP; President, Foundation of Russian Economy 12:00 – 12:20 – Coffee Break 12:20 -13:30 – Sales: International vs. Regional Expansion Case Studies Presenters: Entering the U.S. and European Markets Andrey Korneev , Chief Executive Officer, Research Center Bioform Alex Kosik, СEO, Gravitonus Inc. Developing Regional Businesses Oleg Husaenov, Chairman of the Board, International Automobile Holding, Atlant-M 13:30 – 14:30 – Lunch 14:30 – 17:00 – Creating Effective Business Models Master Class by Patrick van der Pijl, СEO, Business Models Inc. Expert and producer of the global bestseller, “Business Model Generation: A Handbook for Visionaries, Game Changers, and Challengers”. Mr. van der Pijl gave a practical master class on the most effective ways to optimize your organization’s business model to grow your business and increase sales. The world is changing at a high speed. The shelf life of business models becomes shorter and shorter. We need new tools and skills to understand, design and innovate business models. Patrick provided an introduction to why business modelling is so popular, explaining the business model canvas and providing practical examples of how you can innovate and test your own business model. 17:00 – 17:20 – Coffee Break 17:20 – 17:40 - Open Innovation as an Instrument to Grow Entrepreneurial Companies Ekaterina Inozemtseva , Strategy Director, Skolkovo Foundation 17:40 – 18:00 – Creating an Innovation Lab and Managing Innovation in your Business (Case Study) Yan Abubakirov , General manager, a group of companies "TETRA Electric" 18:00 – 18:20 – Signing Ceremony for First Members of the Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development 18:20 – 18:30 – Conference Closing 18:30 – 21:00 – Gala celebration honoring the 10th anniversary of the Center for Entrepreneurship and the Entrepreneurship Ecosystem Awards ceremony Participation fee: The fixed price for all entrepreneurs: 9000 rubles (including VAT); Sponsors: Strategic Partner: Sponsors: Supported by the entrepreneurial companies: Information Partners: Exclusive Sponsor of the reception: Download Material 's presentation (pptx, 1.07 MB) 's presentation (pptx, 1.58 MB) 's presentation (pptx, 1.71 MB) 's speech (ppt, 5.25 MB) Photos 1 of 6 Videos В вашем браузере отключен JavaScript ← Return to Events List © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

New leaders today are those entrepreneurs who were able to overcome the crisis period, running a successfully functioning company and is currently making the transition to the business outlook and values ​​of sustainable business development. All new leaders combine a holistic understanding of success as an effective fusion of business and social achievements, when the achievement of personal and business well-being leads to success and prosperity of society as a whole. The main purpose of the event is to provide entrepreneurs with a platform where they could discuss issues of effective management of a growing company, to share best practices in information technology, personnel management, capital raising, as well as look at entrepreneurship as a source of economic and social spheres of society, the social contract between a businessman and the environment in which it operates. The debate promises to be dynamic, since it is aimed at business owners who want to effectively grow their business, acquire knowledge and establish new contacts and actively participate in solving social problems in Russia. In the first part of the day Dr. Ray Smilor, an expert of world renown in the field of entrepreneurship, will speak on "How to keep the lead: managing growing companies". Further, the conference participants will discuss the use of information technology for business development, as well as take part in one of the thematic sections devoted to finding talent and raising capital. After lunch a discussion on the topic of leadership in public and social life will take place. The official part of the conference report, "Sustainable development and entrepreneurship" will be provided by entrepreneur - Bruce Poon Tip, the founder of the company “Gap Adventures”, internationally recognized for outstanding business solutions. After the main part of the conference participants and guests will take part in the gala evening devoted to the activities of the Center for Entrepreneurship. We will express our appreciation and present commemorative awards to partners and associates of the Centre in development of business environment in Russia. The conclusion of the evening will be devoted to networking. Duration of the conference - from 9:00 to 18:00. The gala party will be held from 18:00 to 20:00. Conference venue - Radisson Royal Hotel (hotel "Ukraine"). We expect about 200 entrepreneurs from Moscow, St. Petersburg and Nizhny Novgorod, representatives of governmental and other organizations within the framework of business support, as well as our international colleagues. FastTrac programs are resources for entrepreneurs that have been developed by and with hundreds of successful entrepreneurs who have shared their knowledge, insights, and stories so that others might learn from them. In 1998 FastTrac won the Small Business Administration`s Model of Excellence Award for Entrepreneurial Education. CFE offers FastTrac Planning as a nine module, 32.5 hour course that allows entrepreneurs to take a hard look at all aspects of their company and write a new business plan to address present and future needs and to help them manage their company on a daily basis. Entrepreneurs learn with a group of peers, entrepreneurs like themselves, who are working to improve their businesses. They also work with certified facilitators, people with real entrepreneurial business experience, who understand the challenges of operating and growing entrepreneurial business ventures. In this supportive environment, they incubate new business ideas, uncover areas that need reinforcing, and establish a foundation from which to make future decisions. © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

The program fosters personalized experience and enables mentors to provide advice not only on business issues, but also general advice as many program participants are just beginning their careers. Mentors serve as a sounding board, provide a second opinion, share lessons from their experiences, and become a trusted long-term relationship. A mentor helps expand a new entrepreneur’s business and social network and access to senior decision makers. This one year program includes pre-program training to introduce both mentors and mentees to the skills, knowledge and attitudes necessary to be effective in their respective roles. Over the course of the year, mentors and mentees meet twice a month and mentees are invited to participate in two CFE Entrepreneurship Groups and two CFE 4-hour open enrollment seminars in order to provide a formal learning element to the program. In order to ensure success of this program, CFE has partnered with the International Business Leaders Forum which lends their program experience in conducting mentoring programs in 37 countries worldwide. © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

Subscribe to receive announcements about upcoming events in your city to receive our e-Bulletin (3 times a year) Last Name First Name Company Title E-mail Telephone City Industry - Agriculture Construction and Real Estate Consulting Food Industry Investor Legal Media NGO Production Other Russian Government Services Technology Transport/Logistics U.S. Government University Education Role Manager Entrepreneur Top Manager Instructor Government Employee Expert Student Other Submit Русский Join us on Facebook Subscribe For announcements of upcoming events and/or our e-Bulletin ﻿ About Programs for Entrepreneurs Entrepreneurship Groups Conferences FastTrac Seminars Mentoring Program Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Program Archive Youth Entrepreneurship Initiatives Matching Funding Resource Center For Donors Partners Contacts Seminars The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) has developed ten, 4-hour training modules specifically for the Russian market. We conducted surveys of entrepreneurs to determine and prioritize the specific training needs of Russian entrepreneurs and enlisted the expertise of worldwide experts and authors in developing the courses. Once the course was written, we translated, localized the material, and trained Russian entrepreneurs to be facilitators of these modules. Because of their effectiveness, our modules have been donated for use in Eastern Europe at the Centers for Entrepreneurship and Executive Development initiated by the Small Enterprise Assistance Funds with USAID support. Topics of CFE 4-hour learning modules include: Making Winning Presentations to Investors: How to Raise Money to Build Your Company By revealing the secrets of what investors look for in making an investment decision, the program helps entrepreneurs successfully pitch their companies — whether they have 60 minutes at a negotiation table, 6 minutes at a conference, or 60 seconds in an elevator. Seminar authored by Dr. Ray Smilor, author and reviewer of 14 books in entrepreneurial leadership. Raising Capital for Growth As the Russian market matures, entrepreneurs increasingly realize that access to capital to finance growth is essential to increasing their company’s competitive advantage. This seminar, developed in Russia and reflecting the realities of this market, takes participants through the investment process so that they understand various sources of capital and the steps needed to obtain investment. Seminar authored by Konstantin Gubin, Partner, RB Partners, Moscow. An Entrepreneur’s Guide to Strategic Planning To survive and prosper in a permanently changing environment, entrepreneurs must think strategically about the internal and external factors impacting their organizations, and the actions to take in response. This seminar provides participants with hands-on training in methods used to support effective and strategic decision making. Seminar authored by Dr. Alex DeNoble, Head of Entrepreneur Training Programs at San Diego State University (USA). The Power of Numbers: How Entrepreneurs Use Financial Statements to Grow Their Businesses Entrepreneurs who really understand what is behind their companies’ numbers are more credible business leaders. This seminar demonstrates to entrepreneurs that financial statements are an effective, compelling, interesting and powerful tool for business development. Seminar authored by Bill McIntire, Kent State University (USA). Cash Flow Management for Growth When the management of a fast-growing company lacks understanding of how to optimize cash flow, a lack of cash inevitably inhibits growth and sometimes leads to bankruptcy. The seminar shows entrepreneurs how to resolve problems associated with cash flow management. Seminar authored by Bill McIntire, Kent State University (USA). Entrepreneurial Marketing By focusing on the unique marketing challenges and opportunities in fast-growth entrepreneurial firms this workshop shows entrepreneurs innovative and cost-effective marketing techniques to win customers and capture markets. Seminar authored by Dr. Mike Morris, Chair of Entrepreneurship Department, Oklahoma State University (USA), and author of four books. Leading a High Performance Company One of the best investments entrepreneurs can make to ensure the success of their growing companies is to invest in the guiding and driving force of the business — themselves. This seminar reveals the secrets of how entrepreneurs can get the most out of their people and their company. Seminar authored by Dr. Jana Matthews, President, Jana Matthews Group (USA), and author of seven books, including one translated into Russian. Hiring and Retaining Key Staff The seminar teaches entrepreneurs to get outstanding people onboard and ensure the employees’ targets are aligned with business goals. Seminar authored by Dr. Jana Matthews, President, Jana Matthews Group (USA), and author of seven books, including one translated into Russian. Corporate Governance for Successful Entrepreneurs This workshop identifies the key provisions of the Russian Code of Corporate Governance and shows entrepreneurs how to adapt and apply them to their companies. Seminar co-authored by Paul Kouris (U.S. corporate law expert) and Alexander Filatov, Executive Director, Independent Directors Association (Moscow, Russia). Implementing the Balanced Scorecard: Maximizing Performance and Creating Sustainable Results What is needed to successfully implement the selected strategy is a system that provides good insight into an organization’s operations and helps align short-term actions with the strategy. One system that does this is a widespread Balanced Scorecard (BSC) model. Seminar authored by Paul Niven, President of Sanalosa Group, and author of four books, including two translated into Russian. © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

Each November, millions of young people from 100 countries participate in tens of thousands of events aimed at joining a growing movement of entrepreneurial people to generate new ideas and to seek better ways of doing things. Global Entrepreneurship Week (GEW) is an initiative of the U.S.-based Kauffman Foundation and Enterprise U.K. It connects young people everywhere through local, national and global activities designed to help them explore their potential as self-starters and innovators. Students, educators, entrepreneurs, business leaders, employees, non-profit leaders, government officials, and many others participate in a range of activities — online and face-to-face — to harness the energy of social networking, to connect people taking action in their local and global communities, and to celebrate entrepreneurship across the globe. - Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Making Winning Presentations To Investors: How to Raise Money To Build Your Company A 4-Hour Workshop for Entrepreneurs Seeking Investment Entrepreneurs may have the best product, the most innovative technology, the largest market or the most detailed business plan, but they may still not be able to secure the capital they need to grow their businesses.  To raise money, entrepreneurs must be able to present their companies and their capabilities in a compelling and effective manner to investors.  This workshop gives entrepreneurs the tools they need to make that winning presentation. The workshop focuses on: Identifying the key factors that entrepreneurs must communicate to investors; What entrepreneurs must never say; What investors look for in making an investment decision; How to present the opportunity; How entrepreneurs should establish their credibility with investors; How entrepreneurs can enhance their image and stature in the minds of investors; Preparing for the presentation; Dealing with stage fright; and Structuring a clear and persuasive message for potential investors. At the end of the training session, a senior Investment Manager from Delta Capital Management, the leading private equity investor in Russia, will speak on what investors look for in potential investment target companies, and answer participants questions. Facilitators Dmitry Vechkanov and George Gorshkov are successful entrepreneurs and Partners at CMG strategy, a marketing consultancy founded in 1994 that works with major international clients, including American Express, PricewaterhouseCoopers, AIG and DeltaCredit, as well as entrepreneur-owned businesses.  Both have conducted seminars and master classes on marketing and business education for The British Council, the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia (AmCham), and the Academy of National Economy (ANE).  They also served as judges for AmChams MBA competition and ANEs business plan competition.  They were both awarded honors degrees from the Academy of National Economy.  As recipients of the Queens Award and the Chevening Awards, they earned their MBAs from the Imperial College Management School in London, which boasts the top-ranked school of entrepreneurship in Europe.  They were both nominated for the Ernst & Young "Entrepreneur of the Year" award in 2003. Time: Seminar from 14:00  18:00 What Past Seminar Participants Say: "My new business partners and I formed a very aggressive business plan for year 2003.  It was a tough decision, because it was a first time for us to launch a really venture business in the high-tech industry, which required an involvement of an outside investor.  We compiled the presentation with some basic ideas.  We spoke about the opportunity , supported by third-party evidence and information.  We spoke about credibility , based on success stories and experience.  We proved our passion for what we do.  And, we calculated precisely the amount of investment funds needed.  The following week, we signed the investment agreement.  Please find our compliments and appreciation for your impact to this success.  It is the best practical implementation of a training session I could ever think of." - Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange The Russia - U.S. Entrepreneurship Forum:  Economic Revitalization Through Entrepreneurship Russia-U.S. Entrepreneurial Forum Event Date:  September 24, 2003 - A healthy climate for entrepreneurship is essential in building a strong economy, creating jobs, opening markets, and raising the standard of living.  The Russian Ministry of Industry, Science and Technology and the United States Department of Commerce, co-organizers of the Russia  US Entrepreneurship Forum, are pleased to invite you to participate in this important event to accelerate economic growth in Russia through entrepreneurship. This unique, all-day Forum will bring together US and Russian entrepreneurs, investors, government officials and scholars to address key issues and develop practical strategies to expand entrepreneurship in Russia, and build better and stronger business ties between Russia and the United States.  The Forum will have four panels, each consisting of two Russian and two American experts discussing: - The use of investment capital as a tool for growth; - The impact of regulatory and infrastructure issues on business start-up and growth; - The role of innovation and technology in economic development, and - The importance of training and education in promoting entrepreneurship. Following the Forum, policy recommendations will be formulated with action plans to further develop entrepreneurship. - Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Cash Flow Management for Growth January 28, 2004 - Moscow, Russia January 30, 2004 - St. Petersburg, Russia As an entrepreneur you took an idea and turned it into reality.  While most businesses never make it past the start-up stage, you beat the odds.  However, after initial success, you now find that a lack of cash is inhibiting your companys growth: affecting strategic planning, product development, and sales.  For your company to grow, cash needs to be available to help managers develop and implement strategy, to fund new products, and to finance sales and marketing campaigns.  With a proper understanding of cash flow management, you can help ensure that your employees have the resources they need to grow your company. Cash Flow Management for Growth teaches entrepreneurs how to solve the cash flow problems faced by growing businesses. The seminar begins with the difference between profit and cash , followed by interactive discussion and problem-solving sessions on the sources and uses of cash in a growth business , the use of the right financial ratios to measure and monitor cash flow, and the relationship between growth and cash flow .  Working with other entrepreneurs you will analyze a case study about a company in a cash flow crisis and develop operational strategies and tactics to help the company survive.  This workshop focuses on you, the entrepreneur, and your understanding of the impact of cash flow on your companys growth. Course Developer & Facilitator Bill McIntyre is the Program Coordinator for the Ohio Employee Ownership Center.  Previously, he was on the Board of Directors and spent 15 years as Chief Financial Officer of ComSonics, Inc., a fast growing high technology company.  He is a frequent speaker at conferences and has taught Financial Accounting, Managerial Accounting and Accounting Systems at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Virginia.  He is a CPA and worked as a consultant at Arthur Andersen.  McIntyre earned his MBA from the Stanford University Graduate School of Business. - Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange An Entrepreneurs Guide to Strategic Planning As a leader of a growing company, you are continually focused on finding and pursuing new opportunities to maintain and accelerate momentum.  Your challenges are compounded by the rapidly changing and turbulent environment in which your firm operates.  To survive and prosper in such settings, you must learn to think strategically about the forces impacting your organization and the actions you must take in response.  Thus, strategic planning is concerned with envisioning how markets are evolving and deciding how best to procure and allocate resources which can help you to be a player in those markets. An Entrepreneurs Guide to Strategic Planning is a workshop designed to provide participants with hands-on training in methods used to support effective strategic decision making . Strategic decisions are those which define a firms future direction and shape the necessary allocation of resources to attain longer term objectives.  Participants will have the opportunity to work with and apply various strategic tools and techniques to their own organizational situations.  Particular emphasis will be placed upon tools for evaluating your firms external environment for critical opportunities and threats and internal environment for an assessment of key strengths and weaknesses.  You will use the insights generated from these tools to formulate a strategic vision for your organization and a strategic plan designed to attain that vision. This program is designed for entrepreneurs, founders and CEOs of growing organizations who: - Wish to bring new products and services into the market place through innovation and creativity. -  Are currently seeking new avenues for growth. -  Desire to move their companies to pursue new opportunities within their existing markets. The Entrepreneurs Guide to Strategic Planning workshop will encompass a series of lectures, discussions, experiential exercises and a case study all designed to enable you to introduce a culture of strategic thinking into your own organization.  From this experience, you will take away a set of tools you can use with your own people to develop a comprehensive strategic assessment of where your firm is today, where it desires to be tomorrow and action plans to get you from here to there, and the knowledge to implement those tools. Facilitator Alex F. DeNoble is a Professor of Management at . As a Director in the , he is in charge of the Entrepreneurship Academic Program, the Venture Challenge International Business Plan Competition and serves as a Board Member for the Center for the Commercialization of Advanced Technologies. His research has been published in various journals including the Journal of Business Venturing, the Journal of High Technology Management Research and Entrepreneurship: Theory and Practice. Dr. DeNoble's other professional activities encompass both executive training and strategic management. Recent clients include Banco Nacional de Commercio Exterior (the National Export Bank of ), NEC Electronics USA, and Shell Technology Ventures. Dr. DeNoble was recently recognized by Ernst and Young as an Entrepreneur of the Year recipient in the Supporter of Entrepreneurship category and by the Price-Babson Fellows Program as a recipient of the Gloria and Edwin Appel Prize for Excellence in Entrepreneurship Education. Dr. DeNoble has a B.A. in Accounting from , a Masters in Accounting and a Ph.D. in Strategic Management from Virginia Polytechnic Institute and . - Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Leading a High Performance Company A 4-Hour Leadership Workshop for Entrepreneurs As an entrepreneur you took a great business idea and started and grew your company  overseeing every step and making the most important decisions.  Now, as your business expands you face new challenges that require more and more of your time and resources.  One of the best investments you can make to ensure the success of your growing company is to invest in yourself as a leader.  By boosting your performance as a leader, you boost the performance of your company by creating a team ready to overcome obstacles and take your company to new levels of success. Leading a High Performance Company focuses on you, the entrepreneur, and your companys growth potential.  Discover how to get the most out of your company and your people at this dynamic workshop, where you will learn the four major components of being a leader of a high performance company: Setting a strong example; Learning to delegate effectively; Measuring the performance of your company and your team; and Rewarding and promoting your best people. Finally, we will also discuss how to de-motivate employees , so that you wont! The Leading a High Performance Company workshop begins with a presentation, followed by an interactive discussion and problem-solving session, and ends with the creation of a Personal Action Plan that you can use immediately.  A networking reception with your fellow entrepreneurs immediately follows the session. Seminar Author - Dr. Jana Matthews is an expert on entrepreneurial leadership, and has written or co-authored six books.  She received her doctorate from Harvard University, and is the founding President and CEO of Boulder Quantum Ventures, that works with founding entrepreneurs, CEOs, corporate executives and top teams to unlock their company's growth potential.  She also consults with Foundations, government agencies and corporations trying to help entrepreneurs commercialize technology and manage growth.  Previously, Dr. Matthews was a senior staff member at the for Entrepreneurial Leadership, where she developed highly successful programs designed to teach entrepreneurs how to manage growth. Seminar Facilitator Dr. Mikhail Klarin earned two levels of PhD from the Russian Academy of Education.  He is the author over 150 publications including books and articles on teaching/training methods, facilitation and group work, adult learning, executive and management development. The latest titles are  Technology of Education , Riga, 1999 and  Corporate Training: A to Z , Moscow, 2000, 2002 (the first and so far the only Russian title on the subject).  Since 1990, Dr. Klarin was an independent management trainer and organizational development consultant, working with executive teams and providing programs for organizational change, developing corporate culture, teambuilding. For seven years, Mikhail was Senior Consultant/Trainer, Center for Business Skills Development (Thunderbird University) working with Russian and multinational companies across CIS and Eastern Europe.  At the Russian Institute of Directors Dr. Klarin presides over the methodology of Corporate Governance Program for members of Boards of Directors and runs training sessions for Boards of Directors on strategic decision-making. He also runs training workshops in executive MBA programs in Moscow. - Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Implementing the Balanced Scorecard:  Maximizing Performance and Creating Sustainable Results As an entrepreneur leading a growing company, you are continually scanning the environment for new markets and opportunities.  You have made the hard strategic decisions which define your firms future direction and shape the necessary allocation of resources to attain your longer term objectives.  You have crafted what looks to be a winning strategy, and are ready to sit back and let it happen.  Right? Wrong!  For those who can execute their strategy, the rewards are significant.  However, its one thing to craft a winning strategy, but successfully implementing it is another thing entirely.  Unfortunately, the vast majority of companies fail miserably when attempting to execute their strategies.  What is needed to successfully implement strategy is a system that provides real insight into an organizations operations, balances the historical accuracy of financial numbers with the real drivers of future performance, and helps align short-term actions with strategy.  One system that does this is the Balanced Scorecard. In this seminar, Implementing the Balanced Scorecard , you will get an in-depth, hands-on examination of the powerful Balanced Scorecard system. You will be exposed to all key facets of the Balanced Scorecard model, allowing you to take full advantage of this breakthrough tool in your own organization.  Through lecture, hands-on exercises, a real-life case study, and actual Balanced Scorecard success stories, you will learn: - How the Balanced Scorecard helps solve fundamental business issues; - How it translates vision and strategy into action; - How to define key performance measurement terms and concepts; - How to determine what to measure in each of the four Scorecard perspectives; and - How to communicate strategy on a strategy map. You will take away a set of tools you can use with your own strategy to develop a comprehensive set of balanced measurements to successfully drive your future results. Facilitator Noted author, speaker and consultant Paul R. Niven. Mr. Niven is the President of Primerus Consulting, and the author of Balanced Scorecard Step-by-Step: Maximizing Performance and Maintaining Results , and Balanced Scorecard Step-by-Step for Government and Nonprofit Agencies .  A former consultant with both KPMG and Computer Sciences Corporation (CSC), his work on performance management has been published in many professional publications.  He is a frequent and popular speaker on the Balanced Scorecard methodology and implementation at seminars around the world.  He may be reached through his web site at: www.primerusconsulting.com . - Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Hiring and Retaining Key Staff A company with great ideas and strong plans cannot grow without the right people in place.  As a business owner, you may wonder, Why cant we hire the right people? or Why are the people we want to stay leaving?  This seminar will show you how to get outstanding people onboard, and how to ensure their goals are aligned with yours.  You will learn how to create a company where your best people want to stay and help you grow. Hiring and Retaining Key Staff was developed by entrepreneurship expert, Dr. Jana Matthews, and addresses the essential issues of finding and keeping the best people in your company. Hiring Key Staff The hiring process can get derailed in many places.  In this seminar, youll learn to solve the common challenges of hiring, by developing a hiring process that works.  You will review your own hiring process, assess its strengths and weaknesses, and identify changes that need to be made.  We will address key questions, such as: What do we need to do before we start a hiring search? How do we identify the best candidates from the ones that are not right for us? How do we get people to reveal who they really are during the interview, not who they want us to think they are? Who should be moved from potential candidates to finalists? What questions should we ask when we do reference checks? How do we negotiate a win-win employment agreement? What red flags should we be watching for during the hiring process? Retaining Key Staff Knowing how to find the right people is just the beginning. You must be able to identify your key staff and retain them (and assess who might need to leave.)  This seminar will teach many of the ways to retain key staff and enable them to be peak performers, including: Getting your new employees off to a strong start. Setting clear performance expectations and measurements. Keeping your employees focused on your companys goals and plans Getting them to execute and produce results Rewarding and motivating your best people Understanding your employees expectations of respect, trust, communication and feedback, and involvement in planning the future of the company. How to manage situations where employees do not produce the expected results or fit with your companys culture Tools to decide whether employees are worth keeping, or whether they have to go. The Hiring and Retaining Key Staff workshop features a presentation and case study followed by an interactive discussion.  The seminar provides tools you can use in your company immediately to develop better job descriptions, conduct hiring interviews, and perform reference checks.  Well review a matrix of Performance and Values, develop a performance improvement plan, and discuss ways to have that difficult discussion with an employee  when you tell them they need to leave.  The seminar concludes with the creation of a Personal Action Plan that will prioritize changes youll need to make in your company. Facilitator As the founder and CEO of Boulder Quantum Ventures, Dr. Jana Matthews has first-hand experience with the issues of growth that she writes and speaks about.  She works with CEOs and their top teams to unlock their company's growth potential.  Dr. Matthews developed and delivered to entrepreneurs in Moscow the acclaimed workshop Leading a High Performance Company for the US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship.  She is currently working with CEOs of growing companies in the USA, the government of New Zealand on an initiative to grow 100 companies to $100 million in 10 years, and the government of South Australia.  Previously, Dr. Matthews was a senior staff member at the Kauffman Center for Entrepreneurial Leadership, where she developed highly successful programs designed to teach entrepreneurs how to manage growth. Dr. Matthews received her doctorate from Harvard University.  She is a popular lecturer and the author of seven books, including Leading at the Speed of Growth , Building the Awesome Organization and Lessons from the Edge . - Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences/Events Entrepreneur Exchange Moscow Entrepreneurship Group - IT for Growth (September 10, 2004) The Moscow Entrepreneurship Group is an ongoing networking and panel event that brings together AmCham members in the investment and service sectors with Russian entrepreneurs of growing companies to discuss topics that educate and are vital to creating a healthy entrepreneurial climate in Russia. Septembers Topic: IT for Growth Confirmed Speakers: Entrepreneur - Stanislav Kostiashkin, owner, Continent Express (Corporate Travel Services).  Mr. Kostiashkin will discuss how he relies on IT as a tool that helps him develop his fast growing company.  He will also take you through a step-by-step case study of his current implementation of an enterprise-wide software solution that he is betting will pay for itself through increased growth through higher productivity and efficiency. Investment Industry - Kirill Dmitriev, Managing Director, Delta Capital Management.  Mr. Dmitriev will discuss how IT can increase the value of a business and its attractiveness to investors.  He will also discuss how investors assist their portfolio companies in formulating and impleneting IT strategy. Service Sector  Mikhail Lyastch, President, CompuLink.  Mr. Lyastch will discuss how growing companies can increase their competitiveness with the help of a good IT strategy (and the problems that arise when there is no strategy), mistakes entrepreneurs make when choosing software packages, and how to optimize IT expenses.  He will also talk about real implementation projects, and how the new IT solutions helped these businesses grow. The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Entrepreneurial Marketing: Why the Entrepreneur Must Know the Marketing Function To build successful companies, entrepreneurs must learn how to do much more with marketing while spending much less.  By focusing on the unique marketing challenges and opportunities in fast-growth, entrepreneurial firms, this workshop shows entrepreneurs how to utilize innovative, powerful and cost-effective marketing techniques to win customers and capture markets. Great marketing begins with a fundamental understanding of your market.  Consequently, this workshop addresses what entrepreneurs need to know about their customers and provides practical tools for helping entrepreneurs gain and keep customers!  By revealing key trends in the emerging marketplace and explaining what they mean, the program helps entrepreneurs develop and implement successful marketing strategies and tactics. The workshop introduces entrepreneurs to a simple but powerful framework for organizing their marketing activities in a customer-centered manner.  It provides entrepreneurs with a practical and effective way to deal with the full-range of marketing decision variables to significantly enhance the value creating capabilities in their firms.  In addition, the workshop presents methods and techniques for discovering new sources of customer value in areas that entrepreneurs often overlook. The workshop shows entrepreneurs how to utilize guerrilla marketing approaches to achieve high impact marketing results without spending large amounts of money.  Entrepreneurs can thus enhance their abilities to leverage resources, stretch resources, discover under-utilized resources and create their own resources.  In addition, by providing examples of a variety of guerrilla methods, the workshop will show entrepreneurs ways in which marketing can be used creatively to mitigate and manage the risks facing their firms. Too many entrepreneurs take a reactive and tactical approach to marketing.  This workshop shows entrepreneurs how to be more proactive and strategic and thus far more effective  in developing and implementing their firms entire marketing program.  In the process, entrepreneurs come to better understand the need for a close relationship between their customers buying process and their firms selling process. In addition to relevant examples and case studies, the program utilizes questionnaires and worksheets so that each entrepreneur walks away with a customized marketing plan that he or she can use to build their companies.  Through this program, entrepreneurs will learn how the right entrepreneurial marketing approach can lead to more profitable enterprises. Facilitators Dmitry Vechkanov and George Gorshkov are successful entrepreneurs and Partners at CMG strategy, a marketing consultancy founded in 1994 that works with major international clients, including American Express, PricewaterhouseCoopers, AIG and DeltaCredit, as well as entrepreneur-owned businesses.  Both have conducted seminars and master classes on marketing and business education for The British Council, the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia (AmCham), and the Academy of National Economy (ANE).  They also served as judges for AmChams MBA competition and ANEs business plan competition.  They were both awarded honors degrees from the Academy of National Economy.  As recipients of the Queens Award and the Chevening Awards, they earned their MBAs from the Imperial College Management School in London, which boasts the top-ranked school of entrepreneurship in Europe.  They were both nominated for the Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year award in 2003. Time: Seminar from 9:00  13:00 What Past Seminar Participants Say: "Its no doubt that I will use the recommended pricing strategy.  Up to now, prices for our companys products (instant oatmeal and kasha) have been pretty much in one price range.  However, we are starting to manufacture products oriented to people whose income is higher than middle-class, and who are health conscious (for example, different fitness-porridges), and therefore we are planning to apply different pricing methodologies for these products. Sergey Vykhodtsev, Bistroff Official Information Date: Wednesday, November 5, 2003 Time: 9:00 am Registration dead-line: Thursday, March 13, 2003 Location: The President Hotel 24, Bolshaya Yakimanka St. Seminar in the Blue Room (2nd Floor) Language: Russian Fee: $125 (includes course materials, and coffee break) Information: contact@cfe.ru Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

Victor Sedov, Executive Director of CFE, agreed to speak on Entrepreneurship at this Aprils Russian Economic Forum in London.  The main theme of Mr. Sedov's presentation was the importance of education and networking for entrepreneurs of mid-size, growth companies. Victor Sedov speaking at the 2003 Russian Economic Forum in London. To his right sits Mitchell Strauss, of OPIC, and Irina Khakimada, member, Russian State Duma Russian Economic Forum Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange The Real Power of Numbers:  How Entrepreneurs Can Use Financial Statements to Grow Their Businesses Investors and bankers place high value on accurate financial statements and realistic, defensible forecasts.  Entrepreneurs who really understand what is behind the numbers of their companies are more credible business leaders and thus are far more likely to get the funding they need to build their firms.  Consequently, it is critical for entrepreneurs to understand and speak intelligently about their financial statements and the key performance metrics and ratios that are essential to their businesses, as well as about the set of key assumptions that form the basis for their financial projections. Entrepreneurs usually have a good feel for their businesses.  They know their products and markets, and they can manage people.  Too often, however, entrepreneurs view financials as necessary but tedious and uninteresting aspects of their businesses that someone else, like an accountant, ought to deal with.  But research shows that the most successful entrepreneurs demonstrate real financial know-how about the critical numbers in their companies.  They recognize that financial statements are valuable sources of information, powerful planning mechanisms and essential tools for managing and growing their businesses faster and more profitably. This program gives entrepreneurs the tools to: Use financial statements in running and expanding their businesses; Read, understand and use critical financial information; Use financial statements to model their businesses; Detect business problems early, before they become critical; Improve their forecasting abilities; Create flash reports based on key financial balances, ratios and other metrics to help manage their businesses better; and Present financial information to bankers and investors more effectively. In addition to relevant examples and case studies, the program utilizes questionnaires and worksheets so that each entrepreneur walks away with a customized set of financial tools that he or she can use to help build their companies.  Through this practical and revealing program, entrepreneurs will learn how their financial statements can be powerful, compelling, interesting and insightful tools to build their companies. Author of the Seminar - Allan Edwin, Ph.D., is President of Edwin & Associates, which specializes in strategic and business planning; joint venture and strategic partnership negotiation; conflict resolution; capital formation; and operational consulting.  As an entrepreneur, Mr. Edwin started and was CEO for 10 years of Interactive Systems, Inc., a computer and communications company that he managed through three rounds of venture funding, and its acquisition by 3M.  Mr. Edwin is a Fellow of the Foundation for Enterprise Development, which has extensive experience in designing and delivering entrepreneurship programs in Russia and worldwide. Seminar Facilitator Mikhail Stepanov graduated from the Moscow State Institute of International Relations.  From 1994 to 2001 he worked in the banking/financial sector. He started his career at the International Finance Corporation (IFC). For three years he was the head of financial services and accounting at the commercial bank Bank Societe Generale Vostok (an affiliated bank of the French Banking Group Societe Generale). He was financial director at the investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson (Dresdner Bank group). He was the head of the financial department at the Russian banking holding Investment Banking Corporation.  Since 2001, Mikhail has been an independent consultant on structuring financial control systems.  He is both an owner and a director of an educational-consulting center. Time: Seminar is from 9:00  13:00 Official Information Date: Thursday, December 4, 2003 Time: 9:00 am Registration dead-line: Thursday, December 4, 2003 Location: President Hotel Bolshaya Yakimanka, 24 Blue Hall (2nd Floor) Language: Russian Fee: $125 (includes course materials and coffee break) Information: contact@cfe.ru Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange The U.S. Russia Entrepreneur Exchange Program On May 20 - 30, 2004, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, along with our partner in the United States, the Foundation for Enterprise Development is sponsoring five Russian entrepreneurs for a 10-day business development and on-site exchange with an American entrepreneur from the same industry. Members of the 2003 US Russia Entrepreneur Exchange in Washington DC, May 2003 Mission To bring together growth entrepreneurs from Russia and the U.S. to learn from each other, get inspiration and validation from their peers, and to expand their networking. Goals 1.  To provide a peer-to-peer learning activity by matching selected Russian entrepreneurs with their U.S. counterparts to exchange ideas and business practices that shape an emerging company. 2.  To immerse Russian entrepreneurs in the American entrepreneurial culture, and expose their American hosts to the business culture of Russia. 3.  To build personal relationships between entrepreneurs within a shared industry sector as a foundation for future business opportunities or trade. Selection Prospective Russian candidates will be screened and chosen through the use of information gathered from an application form and a personal interview with The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE).  Once five Russian entrepreneurs of growing companies have been identified, CFE, with the assistance of our partner organizations the Foundation for Enterprise Development and Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO), will identify U.S.-based entrepreneurs from similar industries, type and size of business, stage of business, etc., for possible matches with their Russian counterparts. Download Application Form Here .  Applications due February 27, 2004. For more information, please call 7(095) 252-7927, or e-mail us at contact@cfe.ru Participants in the 2003 Exchange: On May 28-June 7, 2003 CFE sponsored six Russian entrepreneurs of growing companies on a network learning event to meet and exchange knowledge with American entrepreneurs from the same industry.  The Russian entrepreneurs included: Mikhail Kupriyanov, CEO of Syscom, a flat screen monitor manufacturing company; Alexey Voloshin, CEO of Consoil, a venture finance company; Andrei Korneev, CEO of Bioform, a medical products company; Yelena Ulyanova, CEO of Studio Alisa, a television production company; Dmitry Vechkanov, CEO of CMG Strategy, a marketing consulting company; and Alexander Soloviev, CEO of FIS, a food industry equipment manufacturing company. Official Information Date: Thursday, May 20, 2004 Time: 12:00 pm Registration dead-line: Friday, February 27, 2004 Fee: $2,000.00 (payable in rubles) Information: contact@cfe.ru Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Growth in Competitive Conditions: Faster, Higher, Stronger On April 11, 2003, The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship and the business newspaper Vedomosti co-organized the conference, Growth in Competitive Conditions:  Faster, Higher, Stronger Over 70 growth entrepreneurs, consultants, investment professionals, as well as top managers from large Russian companies participated in the conference that focused on ways to improve company success in Russias increasingly competitive market.  The full day conference was divided into panel discussions, each focusing on an issue growth companies face, including: growth strategies, how to implementing these strategies, and raising capital. Dennis Bugrov from McKinsey & Company discussed Elements of Successful Growth Strategies, outlining examples of international companies, such as Gillette, that have remained strong by acquiring and creating new products (shaving crème, deodorant, etc.) to complement older products that have entered a mature life cycle (razors).  After Mr. Bugrovs presentation, Alexey Evgenev, General Director of Severstalmash, a large conglomerate, spoke about how his company successfully implemented McKinseys growth strategy recommendations.  Elena Chirkova, from Deloitte & Touche, expanded upon this theme and spoke about diversification, using companies such as Revlon, GE, as examples of companies that have used acquisitions to diversify and expand their business. Kirill Dimitriev of Delta Capital Management presented on what private equity funds look for in potential investment targets.  As the audience included growth entrepreneurs who are, or may seek private equity investment in the near future, Mr. Dimitriev outlined important factors in the decision by private equity fund to invest in a growth enterprise, including: Can the fund make money investing in this company? Who will be interested in buying the business in 3-4 years? How much will they pay? What factors will be important to the potential buyer? How much money must be invested, and in what business lines in order to maximize return on investment? How to motivate the management toward the planned sale of the company? CFE invited Vladimir Burenkov, Chair of the Russian Venture Capital Association, to speak about the state of venture capital in Russia.  He first outlined the distinction between venture and private equity capital, and stressed that private equity investment is more prevalent than venture capital because of the high-risk associated with venture investment in Russian start-up companies.  Mr. Burenkov then went on to outline the market sectors which have received the most direct investment, namely the food and telecommunications sectors (25.9% and 25.3% respectively). One of the most fascinating presentations was from Mr. Victor Saks, Director of Strategy and Development at 36.6 an entrepreneur-owned, fast growth pharmaceutical company with a retail chain of 55 pharmacies.  By 2002, 36.6 had a strong brand and a leadership position in its market.  However, it needed funding to support future growth through merger and acquisitions, as the Russian pharmacy industry is entering a phase of consolidation.  Mr. Saks outlined 36.6s decision to raise capital via a Russian IPO versus pursuing direct-equity investment.  36.6 chose an IPO because it gave its owners the best opportunity to retain control over the company, and it forced the company to become transparent, which will facilitate mergers and acquisitions and access to future capital.  Finally, a listing in Russia is obligatory before a company can issue ADRs, a long-term goal.  36.6 went public on February 6, 2003 and raised $14.4 million through the sale of 1.6 million shares, or 20% of the companys shares. Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Corporate Governance for Successful Entrepreneurs Successful entrepreneurs understand a critical fact about investors  they place their funds with a company that is transparent, and governed by a system that provides them with certain rights, a steady flow of information, and specific safeguards.  Cutting-edge technology, market share, or even the most experienced team mean nothing to investors unless they are confident that they are placing their money in an enterprise that will treat them fairly.  To raise capital for their growing companies, entrepreneurs must create this confidence in the minds of potential investors.  One of the most powerful ways to do this is by establishing a credible system of corporate governance.  This workshop shows entrepreneurs how to create such a system, and in the process increase their chances of raising capital for their growing companies. Corporate governance is the set of rules that define the relationship between a company, its shareholders and the community.  The more effectively entrepreneurs implement these rules, the better the relationships they build, and the faster their companies grow.  This workshop identifies the key provisions of the Russian Code of Corporate Governance and shows entrepreneurs how to adapt and apply them to their companies.  Through real-world examples and case-based scenarios, entrepreneurs will learn: How an effective disclosure policy will inspire investor confidence in the companys management; How to select, structure and work with a Board of Directors to better manage the company; How to best utilize outside auditors to insure credible financial reporting; What rights to provide shareholders and investors to keep them informed of company developments; and How to address conflicts between shareholders and management to maintain trust in the organization. This workshop will help entrepreneurs develop and implement practical solutions to corporate governance issues.  It will expose entrepreneurs to universally accepted good corporate governance practices so that they can develop a system that best fits their companys needs. Investors want to place their money in an enterprise that discloses everything they need to know about the company before investing, and then keeps them appraised on the progress of the company after they invest.  Through worksheets, cases, relevant examples and interactive discussion, entrepreneurs will walk away from this workshop with a customized corporate governance structure that can help them insure investor confidence and increase their chances of attracting capital.  They will learn the need for fair, timely and accurate disclosure of information, the optimal structure of their board of directors, and the powerful role of corporate governance in making their companies more successful. Course Developer and Facilitator Paul Kouris is a corporate attorney with extensive international experience counseling on matters relating to corporate governance, financing, employee ownership, privatization and securities issues.  He is a renowned corporate governance expert who has worked with hundreds of entrepreneurs and taught in several countries. Official Information Date: Thursday, May 22, 2003 Time: 2:00 pm Location: President Hotel Language: English with simultaneous Russian translation Fee: $250 (includes course materials and coffee break) Information: contact@cfe.ru Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Understanding the Importance of Corporate Governance for Entrepreneurs

May 22, 2003

The Center for Entrepreneuership Workshop on Corporate Governance

Successful entrepreneurs understand the critical importance of corporate governance in attracting investor confidence and raising capital for their growing companies. This workshop equips entrepreneurs with the knowledge to establish a credible corporate governance system and enhance their chances of securing investments.

Key Provisions and Practices for Effective Corporate Governance

Learn more about how corporate governance can build better relationships with shareholders, inspire investor confidence, improve financial reporting, and address conflicts within the organization. By implementing good governance practices, entrepreneurs can create a transparent and trustworthy environment for investors.

- Learning Programs russian version Workshops Conferences Entrepreneur Exchange Moscow Entrepreneurship Group (June 2003) The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship and AmChams Enterprise Development Committee held its first Moscow Entrepreneurship Group to discuss Raising Capital.  The Moscow Entrepreneurship Group is an ongoing networking and panel event that brings together entrepreneurs of growing companies with investment and service sector professionals to discuss topics that educate and are vital to creating a healthy entrepreneurial culture in Russia. Speakers on the Raising Capital Panel: Investment Industry  Kirill Dmitriev, Vice President, Delta Capital Management.  Mr. Dmitriev discussed what equity funds look for in investment targets, and common mistakes entrepreneurs make when seeking investment. Entrepreneur  Dmitry Agarunov, Owner, GameLand (Publisher of seven magazines, including Svoi Business).  Mr. Agarunov talked about the process he went through to obtain private equity investment to fund the expansion of his growing publishing business. Service Sector  Yuri Mostovoy, CEO, RosBusinessConsulting International.  Mr. Mostovoy discussed his companys recent IPO, and steps entrepreneurs need take in order to obtain equity funding. page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Raising Capital Panel Discussion

June 2003

Inaugural Entrepreneurship Group Discusses Raising Capital Challenges

The Center for Entrepreneurship held its first entrepreneurship group to discuss raising capital. This ongoing networking and panel event brings together entrepreneurs of growing companies with investment and service sector professionals to discuss topics vital to creating a healthy entrepreneurial culture. The panel included experts from various industries. Kirill Dmitriev, Vice President at Delta Capital Management, discussed what equity funds look for in investment targets and common mistakes entrepreneurs make when seeking investment. Entrepreneur Dmitry Agarunov, owner of GameLand, shared his experience of obtaining private equity investment to fund the expansion of his publishing business. Yuri Mostovoy, CEO of RosBusinessConsulting International, discussed his company’s recent IPO and the steps entrepreneurs need to take to obtain equity funding. The event generated valuable insights for all attendees and was a stepping stone towards a more collaborative entrepreneurial ecosystem.

Key Organizations Contributing to the Event

Delta Capital Management is a prominent investment firm known for its focus on funding innovative startups and businesses. Their expertise in identifying high-potential investment opportunities has made them a leader in the equity funding space. GameLand, under the leadership of Dmitry Agarunov, is a successful publishing company that has expanded significantly through strategic equity investments. They publish multiple magazines, catering to a diverse audience, and have set a benchmark in the publishing industry. RosBusinessConsulting International, a comprehensive business services provider, successfully completed an IPO, showcasing their robust business model and growth potential. Their insights into equity funding and IPO processes offer practical knowledge to other aspiring entrepreneurs.

The Alliance activities are focused on providing Russian entrepreneurs access to international and national entrepreneurship events, educational programs targeting prospective entrepreneurs, and initiatives that promote entrepreneurship as the foundation of economic well-being, and that create a favorable environment for innovation.  The Alliance also promotes entrepreneurship education methodology by promoting entrepreneurship programs in universities and conducting trainings for professors. The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- Partners russian version Young Entrepreneur Organization Young Entrepreneur Organization CFE is a founding partner of the Young Entrepreneurs' Organization (YEO) Moscow Chapter.  The chapter was officially launched on February 6, 2003 with a reception that was attended by YEO members, potential members, Russian government officials, as well as the media. (Read more about the YEO Moscow chapter launch.) CFE with founding members of YEO's Moscow Chapter - Moscow, November 2002 Victor Sedov introducing YEO members at chapter launch - Moscow, February 2003 CFE and YEO Members with YEO President Sean Magennis - Paris, October 2002 Victor Sedov, CFE Executive Director with US Ambassador Leach - Paris, October 2002 YEO, through its educational and networking activities, assists young entrepreneurs in building their companies.  YEO members must be younger than 39, and be a founder or co-founder, owner or controlling shareholder of a company with gross annual sales that exceed $1 million.  While some YEO members own companies with sales over $1 billion, the typical company revenue is $9 million. CFE recruited four Russian entrepreneurs to be founding members of the Moscow chapter, and accompanied them to YEO's European Conference in Paris, France.  CFE is assisting in developing and implementing the Moscow chapter's learning programs, and is co-sponsoring YEO's 2003 European Conference where 250 entrepreneurs from Europe and around the world will gather in Moscow to meet with their Russian counterparts for learning and networking events. (Read more about the YEO 2002 European Conference.) YEO is an excellent opportunity for Russian entrepreneurs to network with their peers from around the world and to make contacts that can expand their business.  To learn more about joining the Moscow chapter of YEO, please call (095) 252-7927. Opinion from YEO Moscow Chapter President: "Please accept my warmest compliments for the supportive role [CFE] played in organizing the Russian entrepreneurs' trip to the Paris conference held by YEO in November.  Participation in the Paris forum increased my desire to participate in YEO in Russia.  Moreover, the word about YEO has spread among my associates, many of whom want to join the chapter.  I believe that we have great potential to establish an active and beneficial organization for Russian business owners." Mikhail Kupriyanov, Syscom Read the article in entrepreneur.com Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- Partners russian version Young Entrepreneur Organization European Conference 2002 Young Entrepreneurs Gather in Europe YEOs European Conference Draws 50 CEOs to Paris Washington, DC, USA - Some 50 successful business-owners from 12 countries (Netherlands, Germany, France, England, Switzerland, Russia, Sweden, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Mexico, Canada and the United States) gathered in Paris recently to connect with their business peers and to address relevant business issues through a variety of panel discussions, workshops and keynote speaker presentations. With the Young Entrepreneurs' Organization's (YEO) European membership growing at such an accelerated pace, this special YEO conference provided members with the chance to meet and network with their worldwide entrepreneurial peers. Many of the program's speakers talked on the theme: European Entrepreneurship: A New Reality -- the passion of business in Europe. Profiled speakers included Pierre Cuilleret, founder of The Phonehouse; Mark Dixon, founder of Regus; Glen Travers, biotech entrepreneur; and boat designer Bertrand Vogele of ACM. Other speakers at the three-day conference included: Jean-Francois Ott, a real estate investor in Eastern Europe; Verne Harnish, CEO of Gazelles, Inc.; Gary Hoover, founder of Hoovers Online and Bookstop; Robert Benninga, founder Mind Power International; Frank Mermoud from the Bureau of Economic and Business Affairs (trade), U.S. Department of State; as well as heavy-weight boxer Arnold Vanderlyde, an Olympic silver medalist, who drew parallels between success in sports and success in business. The conference opened with a welcoming reception at residence of the U.S. Ambassador of France Howard H. Leach. There was also a Peer-to-Peer Exchange  dialogue among participants in a round-table-style setting, and a Lessons-From-the-Edge Panel, where participants had the opportunity to hear and tell business stories by people who have been to the edge, overcame monumental hurdles, and not only survived, but thrived in their businesses. The Paris conference was the strongest event in Europe to take place to date, stated Brien Biondi, chief executive officer of YEO. The high-quality learning program was very well received by all who attended. We look forward to the 2003 European Conference taking place in Russia, which will be hosted by our newest YEO chapter located in Moscow. Further information about YEO can be obtained online from www.yeo.org . Further information about the European Conference can be obtained online from the conference website .
